PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes: Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Senators assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens of Australia points out the aged and disabled people who require accommodation and support in nursing homes are entitled to the highest possible standard and quality of nursing care.

We, the petitioners, request the Parliament to ensure that provision of funds for nursing homes in Victoria is sustained at least at a level sufficient to maintain the high standard of care now available in nursing homes in the State.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Alston (from 199 citizens), Button (from 359 citizens), Cooney (from 192 citizens) and McGauran (from 183 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Food Irradiation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
That there is widespread concern by farmers and consumers, about the proposal to irradiate food in Australia. Your petitioners, most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, should:
(1) block the introduction of food irradiation into Australia.
(2) ban the import of cobalt-60 and caesium-137 and caesium-134 to be used to irradiate food products.
(3) ban the import of all machinery used for food irradiation (electron beam, X-ray etc.)
(4) ban the importation and sale of irradiated food in Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Commission
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
1. That the constitution of the Commonwealth has served Australia well, is not out of date, has proved to be flexible and should not be radically altered.

2. Our deep concern that the recommendations of the constitutional commission and its advisory committees which propose radical changes to the constitution are threatening to reduce our rights as citizens of the Commonwealth.

3. Our strongest opposition to any referendum proposals of the Hawke government which gives more power to the government and less to the people and which concentrates that power in Canberra at the expense of the States and weakens the role of the Senate.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation: Commercial Sponsorship
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate of the Commonwealth Parliament assembled. The petition of those residents of the Commonwealth of Australia respectfully showeth:
that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation provides the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia with the only nation-wide, independent radio and television service.
that the independence of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation must be preserved in the interests of the citizens of the Commonwealth of Australia.
that the introduction of commercial sponsorship or any form of advertising material from commercial sources, would destroy the independence of the Corporation.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Honourable Senators will oppose the introduction of any form of sponsorship or advertising material from commercial sources into the programmes of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth:
(1) That we oppose timed local calls by Telecom.
(2) Timed calls should not be introduced in the absence of widespread community support.
(3) Timed calls will seriously affect pensioners, the elderly, low income earners and other disadvantaged groups.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: PROPOSED SELECT COMMITTEE ON AGRICULTURAL AND VETERINARY CHEMICALS IN AUSTRALIA

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-On page 7 of the Australian newspaper today appears a report headed `Senate probe into dangers of agricultural chemicals'. The article has the by-line Alison Barclay. The article is very brief, and I will read it:

SPEECH.PARA: A Senate inquiry has been launched into the dangers posed by agricultural chemicals to health and the environment.
The select committee on agricultural and veterinary chemicals will investigate the administration systems for chemical use and the social and economic impact of the substances.
It will also examine proposed legislation on arrangements for chemical use.
Releasing the committee's terms of reference, Democrat Senator Janet Powell said the inquiry came at a time of increasing concern about the effects of chemical residues in food.

``In recent times farm leaders and agricultural ministers have called on Australia to lead the world in producing clean, unpolluted and residue-free produce, precisely because it is this produce which is in great demand in overseas markets and will increasingly be demanded by the domestic market,'' Senator Powell said.

``The Democrats are convinced that Australian farmers and policy planners must take heed now of the warning signs from within Australia and overseas and look seriously at the future implications of chemical usage and the alternatives of non-chemical and integrated management systems.''
The committee will present a progress report in February next year.

The truth of the matter, as every senator should know-and as I believe Senator Powell would know-is that that Senate committee has not been established. It was not established yesterday and it may never be established.

TALK.START.PARA: —It should not be if there is any justice.

—As Senator Boswell said, it should not be if there is any justice. It should not be under any circumstances. Nevertheless, that report is totally false. When I saw that I thought, `This is quite unbelievable. How could this happen?'. I made some inquiries and I discovered that yesterday a media release apparently was issued by Senator Janet Powell's staff which announced a Press conference in the Australian Democrats' party room to be held at 12.30 p.m. yesterday. At 12.30 p.m. yesterday the debate on when the establishment of the committee should be considered by the Senate had been over for some hours, and it was quite clear to everyone by 12.30 p.m. that the debate on the establishment of this committee might not take place for some months and that the committee might never be established, especially if the Government started to see the wisdom of not establishing it. The media release is entitled:

SPEECH.PARA: Issue: Establishment of Senate inquiry into agricultural and veterinary chemicals.
A journalist who does not understand the sort of language that Senator Powell uses might believe that that meant that that committee had been established. The media release then goes on to say:

Senator Janet Powell, Australian Democrats spokesperson on Primary Industry, has successfully gained Government support for her moves to establish a Senate Select Committee into Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals.
Apparently the Government is prepared to support the establishment of this committee if the Democrats can get this matter up for debate. I go back to the media release. It went on to say:
Senator Powell will outline the reasons for such an inquiry, and the Terms of Reference will be provided at the Press Conference.
For further information: Heather Jeffcoat 062 72 7790
As I said, a journalist who does not understand the sort of language that Senator Powell uses-and she is a devious person; she has been shown to be that on a number of occasions--

That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1988 is to make three amendments to the consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974. They result from the developments since the last major revision of the Trade Practices Act in 1986. Let me say at the outset that the Opposition supports this Bill, although it will be suggesting a variation to one of the Government's three proposals. Of the three amendments proposed by the Government, we support two. In respect of the third, we believe that the Government's proposal should be varied, not, I stress, because of any anti-consumer protection attitude on our part-on the contrary-but rather because the specific proposal of the Government involves a pre-empting by it of the rights of the States as contained in the Federal Constitution. To this extent the proposal is consistent with the Hawke Labor Government's overall centralist thrust, a thrust to put more and more power into Canberra's hands by whittling away the rights of the States in a continual and insidious manner.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me now deal with the Government's three proposals. The first provides that a corporation, and in some cases an individual, shall not, in trade or commerce, falsely represent that goods or services are of a particular value. The amendment clarifies the scope of the prohibitions contained in the existing paragraphs 53 (a) and (aa) of the Act. Mr Justice Ryan of the Federal Court of Australia, in Ducrett v. Chaudhary's Oriental Carpet Palace Pty Ltd (1987) in reports 40-804 indicated that a representation as to value may be a representation as to quality as defined in existing section 53; but whether it does or does not depends upon the facts of each case. The amendment proposed by the Government should, in the words of the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh), `remove any doubt that section 53 prohibits false representations as to the value of goods and services'. We think that is a sensible amendment and we support it.

The second amendment proposes the repeal of section 65U of the Trade Practices Act. That section is a sunset clause on the application of the product safety and product information provisions in the Act to food and drink for human consumption, which will take effect on 1 July 1988. Section 65U was originally inserted at the request of some sectors of the food industry in order to give the States the opportunity to put specific and, hopefully, uniform food recall legislation in place. Those industry sectors argued at the time that food recalls should be controlled under State food law rather than under the Trade Practices Act.

The Government argues that if section 65U were not repealed the Commonwealth would not necessarily even know of a food safety problem and the recall may be conducted on a State basis with little or no coordination to ensure national consumer protection. If section 65U were left in the Act without any amendment, it would have the effect of removing entirely food and beverage from the scope of division 1a of the Act from 1 July 1988. Division 1a deals with product safety standards, the banning of unsafe consumer products and the recall of consumer products with safety related defects.

The Government's third amendment is administrative in nature, resulting from the transfer of responsibility for the enforcement of part IV, division 1A of the Act from the Trade Practices Commission to the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs. Consistent with the practice of the Commission, the amendment will allow persons authorised by the Secretary of the Department to institute proceedings for alleged contraventions of the Act without being required to obtain the prior consent in writing of the Minister.

As I said earlier, the Opposition supports this Bill. In particular, we support the first and third of the Government's proposals, that is, to amend section 53 to include the word `value' as one of the criteria in determining false representation, and to allow authorised officers of the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs, to which responsibility for the enforcement of the consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act is to be transferred from the Trade Practices Commission, to institute prosecutions in a manner similar to prosecutions instituted by officers of the Commission.
The one part of the Bill with which the Opposition has difficulty is the Government's proposal to repeal section 65u of the Trade Practices Act. That section reads:

At the expiration of 2 years after the day on which this Division comes into operation, this Division shall cease to have effect in respect of goods which are foods and drinks intended for human consumption.

The division in question is part V, division 1A. The date of commencement of the operation of that division was 1 July 1986. As I said earlier, if no action at all is taken in respect of the existing section 65u, division 1a will cease to apply to food and drink for human consumption as from 1 July 1988; that is, in a little over two months time.

Section 65u is a classic sunset clause, and it is for this reason that the Government is proposing its repeal. Like the Government, the Opposition does not wish division 1a to cease to apply to food and drink for human consumption as from 1 July 1988. But our reasons are somewhat different from the Government's. The Liberal and National parties believe that by seeking to repeal section 65u rather than to replace it the Government is deliberately attempting to pre-empt the rights of the States in relation to consumer affairs. I accept that the States have had two years in which to introduce their own legislation in this area. So far, as I understand it, only two States have done this-Queensland and Western Australia. The Opposition believes it is the responsibility of the Hawke Government to encourage the remaining States to introduce relevant legislation. If the Government's proposal is accepted, it will no longer have this responsibility. In our view, it will have abdicated its responsibility. What is worse, it will have taken yet another step along its inexorable path of centralisation. It will be one more step by this centralist, socialist Government to whittle away the rights of the States, to undermine the position of the States in our Federation and to white-ant our federal system and, through this process, our very finely balanced democratic structure.

The people of Australia should never forget that the whole aim of this Government is to centralise all political power in Canberra, to reduce the States and local government to political impotency. That means reducing to impotency the will of the Australian people and their rights, because the further we remove the centre of political power from the grassroots-away from the people-the more we alienate the basic democratic political rights and power of the people. This has always been the long term game plan of the Australian Labor Party (ALP). It does not make any bones about that; it does not hide it. That game plan has not altered one iota under the Hawke socialist Government. For these reasons, at the committee stage of the debate I will be moving an amendment to extend the sunset clause provision of section 65u for a further two years, that is, until 1 July 1990. This will give the States a two-year extension in which to implement the decision for uniform State legislation taken by the Standing Committee of Ministers for Consumer Affairs, rather than subject them to the pre-emptive dead hand of a centralist Hawke Labor Federal Government approach. I believe the Opposition's amendment has been circulated to honourable senators; I will have more to say about it at the committee stage.

I now turn to several other matters relative to the Trade Practices Act and consumer affairs generally. First, I will make quite clear the coalition's attitude towards consumerism. The Liberal Party and the National Party are committed to the protection of the interests of the consumer. In fact, it was a Liberal-National Party government-the Fraser Government-which established the first ministry and department of business and consumer affairs and, in fact, it was one of the very first departments established by the new Fraser Government in 1975. It was that same Fraser Government that established the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council, which today is so influential in its role as adviser to Federal and State Ministers with responsibility for consumer affairs.

Unlike what appears to be the view of the Labor Party and what is certainly the view of its increasingly powerful Left and Centre Left factions, the Liberal and National parties believe that there is no inherent conflict of interest between producers and consumers in a private enterprise system. The Labor Party and the free enterprise Liberal and National parties share a common objective of consumer sovereignty in consumer affairs. We both share that objective. However, we differ greatly in our respective approaches to the achievement of consumer sovereignty. The coalition's approach is that the sovereignty of the consumer is best enhanced by making the marketplace more efficient and more competitive through appropriate macro-economic policies and industry policies and by reducing the regulation and restriction of the private enterprise system to the optimum extent. We believe that the effective working of competition in the marketplace provides overall the best benefits to, and protection of, the consumer. That is not to say that there is no need for consumer protection provisions in the law-of course there is.

The coalition has always supported such appropriate provisions. However, it is very important not to get these provisions out of perspective, not to place undue emphasis or reliance on them relative to other issues that concern consumer interests. I believe that that is what the Labor Party has done. The basically regulatory approach to consumer affairs of the Labor Party and the Hawke Government is confrontationist, costly and restrictive. I believe that the way in which the Trade Practices Act contributes most to the well-being of consumers is through its provisions to foster and strengthen effective competitive in the marketplace-not, as Labor would have us believe, through its consumer protection provisions and its huge network of committees, councils and advisory groups, many of them stacked with Labor's friends and mates. I will come back to that matter later.

The Trade Practices Act has not been thoroughly reviewed or overhauled for many years-if ever. It has been amended in an ad hoc fashion over the years by successive governments but without our sitting back and taking a long, hard, objective and dispassionate view of where it stands in its totality. I believe that it is high time that we did just that, because I have a strong feeling that the Act is out of balance in its approach to the various components of trade practices, including protection and consumer affairs.

I alluded earlier to the politicisation of consumer affairs, and I shall now further develop that point, as this is an issue about which the Liberal Party has been concerned for several years. It began under the Whitlam Government, while the Hawke Government has brought it to the level of an art form. The Australian Labor Party's official stated policy is to `provide for direct consumer representation' on the plethora of boards, committees and inquiries that it has established in the consumer affairs area.

With very few exceptions the so-called consumer representation comes from the small select group of consumer activists and advocates who make up the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations, better known as AFCO, and the Australian Consumers Association, better known as ACA. AFCO receives almost 100 per cent of its ongoing funding from the Federal Government. That organisation and the ACA have also been the beneficiaries of State Labor government largess, at the taxpayers' expense. For example, in one six-week period alone the former New South Wales Labor Government gave the ACA $100,000 to conduct surveys of supermarket prices. It is extremely doubtful whether consumers benefit at all from that type of activity, but certainly the activists in the consumer movement do.

Despite its grandiose title, AFCO is actually a very unrepresentative organisation. It certainly is not representative of consumers generally, as it parades itself to be. For example, although its governing body comprises 20 member councils, by far the largest of which is the ACA, there are only 200 people with voting rights. As few as 59 votes have been cast in its elections, and in the past seven years its membership has grown by only 47 people. AFCO's claims that it truly represents the interests of consumers is a sham. Its approach is governed by an overriding ideology, which essentially is anti-business and highly politicised. The politicising of the consumer movement in Australia mirrors, of course, developments in other Western nations. A former Minister in the Hawke Government, John Brown, has been reported as having described AFCO as being run by `the radical Left of the New South Wales Labor Party'. A former Director of AFCO, Mr Allan McCann, has described the Executive of the Federation as being `stacked with members all heavily in favour of the radical side of politics'. Mr McCann claimed that the Australian Consumers Association was `in the control of a clique carrying on the fight in the left-wing of the Labor Party in NSW'.

At the time to which Mr McCann was referring the Manager of the ACA Public Affairs Unit was Mr Allan Asher. Mr Asher has recently been appointed by the Hawke Government as a full time member of the Trade Practices Commission, an appointment of which I and others in the chamber, notably Senator Bronwyn Bishop, have been highly critical. Our criticism has been echoed by large sections of the business community. The appointment obviously concerns the business community, as it concerns many others. A leading public affairs consultant, Mr Bob Browning, who has been critical of the orientation of the Australian Consumers Association, said recently that Mr Asher's appointment:
threatens the objectivity of the Commission-
and-
erodes the democratic process by extending the already excessive influence over public policy and administration of the Australian Consumers Association.

I believe that this appointment, along with many other appointments of the Government in recent years, raises very important questions about the nature of the appointments to important administrative bodies of government. If we are not very careful those appointments will diminish, if they have not already diminished-and I think they probably have-the confidence in the impartiality of those bodies.

The Australian Labor Party will have only itself to blame if its support for persons with Left leaning and radical views on consumer affairs backfires, because it is the Labor Party which has brought these people and their organisations to the fore through key appointments and very generous funding. As I said earlier, the roots of this go back to the Whitlam years. I happened to see an interesting interview on television this morning. Ross Gittins, interviewed on the Good Morning Australia show, commented on the consumer conference taking place at the moment. Mr Gittins made the very interesting and important point that the great danger in terms of where we are going with consumer credit-but he was relating his comments to consumerism generally-is that we are setting up a small group of unrepresentative people who influence an enormous range of decisions of a paternalistic nature by saying to the Australian people that they, this small group of people with a particular ideological bent in terms of regulation and ideology, are going to know better than the consumers themselves what is in the consumers' best interests. I think Mr Gittins's point this morning and his use of the word `paternalism' in that context were very important indeed.

The concern about these developments goes much wider than merely a concern for the direction of consumer affairs as such. At a recent symposium entitled `Business Regulation, when does the consumer profit?', an AFCO representative said, amongst other things:
The outcome of the regulate debate will significantly shape the legal and social and environment of the Australian economy-
I think it should have been `legal and social context'-
in the years to come.

That pitches an agenda far wider than just the question of consumer protection and consumer affairs. What it really seems to be putting straight on the line-nothing hidden about it-is that AFCO, and particularly its member bodies, have a much wider agenda of radical social change to the whole structure of this country. I think that that is an extraordinarily disturbing trend that has not yet been brought home fully to the Australian people, and if it is not we will finish up going a long way down the road to which I referred earlier of paternalism and regulation in a whole range of areas and that will be at great cost to this nation.

Through the attacks of consumer organisations on a host of industries we have seen that they have adopted an anti-business attitude which puts much of the private sector, the productive sector of this country, at risk. Some of the absolutely disgraceful unresearched reports that have come out in the Australian Consumers Association magazine Choice in recent months are a matter of the greatest concern. In Melbourne in my State a small pate manufacturer has been affected. Last year the magazine carried a report on the pate industry, which has suffered dreadfully because of that totally biased and unresearched report. It did not in any way touch in its research on that manufacturer, or indeed on any other manufacturer in Victoria. It was a blatant, misleading article which has put an admittedly small industry, but there are others that one can point to, at very great risk.

A few months ago I spoke in this place on some of these matters, particularly the role of AFCO and the Australian Consumers Association. As a result, I received a very wide range of comments and responses from the community. One of those raised with me two points which I believe are very important. I hope that the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) will follow these up for me, if not in the course of this debate then not long thereafter. In fact, I have a question on notice for him in relation to the rules for AFCO representatives. That is one of the two points. I have been advised that the ACA frequently tests imported goods for the Australian Customs Service. If it does, I would like to know whether the ACA is paid for the testing. If it is, does the testing go out to public tender or is it a preselected arrangement? For example, I understand that the ACA got $90,000 for its food irradiation report. I would like to know what goods the ACA tests and how much it is paid for that. What is the security situation in relation to its test results?

That touches on the second point I want to raise; that is, the rules for AFCO representatives. As I said, many representatives of AFCO and representatives appointed by AFCO to government bodies have been given guidelines by AFCO as to their conduct in these forums. I understand that AFCO has warned its members that their first loyalty is to AFCO even when they are on government bodies which expect persons, once appointed, to serve the public as individuals, not AFCO instruments, and to put consumer, not consumerist, views. AFCO has addressed all members, saying:
Appointees are regarded by AFCO as accountable to the Federation-
that is, AFCO-
and obliged to act in the interests of the Federation.

If that is so-and I have no reason to believe it is not-what on earth does that mean for the impartiality of government bodies? What it means quite simply is that no government body which has on it an AFCO representative could in any way be regarded as being impartial. I am interested in that context to see Senator Gietzelt sitting in the chamber listening to this debate. In the early 1980s and, I think, the late 1970s he was one of the key promoters of the thrust for these sorts of representatives and the involvement of these people in Labor Party appointed consumer affairs bodies. As most, if not all, of AFCO's executive are ALP members or supporters, and as AFCO is in close liaison with the Federal ALP Caucus subcommittee on consumer affairs, might it not be reasonably assumed that the Government is tempted to usurp the voice of consumers for its own ends? The link between the ALP, AFCO and the appointments to consumer affairs bodies is of major concern because it brings government, business and individual privacy and confidentiality into question. AFCO has also said:

For various reasons bodies on which AFCO is represented decide or are required to maintain confidentiality over all or some of their work. AFCO considers that such confidentiality should not preclude its representatives from seeking advice from others in the Federation on a limited basis.

That is an extraordinarily serious statement and I hope that in the context of replying in this debate the Minister and other senior representatives of the Government on the other side of the chamber will take those points into account. Finally, I reiterate that the Opposition supports the Bill with the exception of the variation we wish to see to the Government's proposal in relation to section 65u and we will not oppose the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Senator Short has said, the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1988 amends three sections of the Trade Practices Act: section 53, section 65u and the section relating to the ability of the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs to authorise prosecutions without depending upon the authorisation of the Minister. The first of the proposed amendments, that to section 53, provides that a corporation and, in some cases, an individual shall not in trade or commerce falsely represent that goods or services are of a particular value. In simple terms, the amendment inserts the word `value' as one of the criteria in determining false representation.

SPEECH.PARA: The necessity for this amendment arose from the Chaudhary case to which the Minister for Consumer Affairs (Senator Bolkus) referred in his second reading speech. In this case, Chaudhary's Oriental Carpet Palace ran an advertising campaign which the prosecutor alleged contained misleading statements with respect to the price of certain carpets. One of the allegedly offending statements was that the price of one type of carpet was `Usually $4,675, sale price $1,759, now only $497'. In another part of the advertisement an illustration of another type of carpet was accompanied by a drawing of a price ticket which bore the legend `usually $250, sale price $125, now only $12.50'. The prosecutor alleged that the statements were misleading because they indicated that the usual or fair retail prices of the carpets in Melbourne, where this was taking place, were $4,675 and $250, which allegedly was not the case.

Expert evidence was adduced that it was impossible to specify a single specific price as the usual retail price in Melbourne of rugs of a particular size and type. The charges against the company were dismissed on the basis that the actual advertisement in this case did not contain a statement which indicated either the usual retail price or a fair price or a fair retail value of a rug to which the advertisement referred. However, the decision allowed for the possibility that in some circumstances goods had a definite degree of some reasonable characteristic which was recognised or so widely accepted within the relevant trade or by commercial practice generally that to ascribe that value to them in, say, an advertisement was inferentially to warrant that they were of a standard likened to that value. In short, Justice Ryan of the Federal Court of Australia indicated that a representation as to the value may be a representation as to quality, as defined in the existing section 53. Whether it does or not depends on the facts of each case. The amendment in this legislation, therefore, is clearly desirable in that it will remove any doubt that section 53 prohibits false representations as to the value of goods and services.

The second amendment in this Bill proposes the repeal of section 65u of the Act, which is a sunset clause on the application of the product safety and product information provisions in the Act to food and drink for human consumption. It will take effect on 1 July 1988. As honourable senators are, I am sure, aware, that sunset clause was inserted into the Act in 1986 by Democrats' Leader Senator Janine Haines. Despite Government protests at that time during the debate on that Bill, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples) acknowledged in another place that Senator Haines's intentions were good. Basically Senator Haines's intention was to give the industry time in which to pressure the States into introducing in the area of food and drink supply and sale consumer protection legislation which was uniform and incorporated all the requirements contained in the Federal trade practices legislation. Senator Haines said at the time:

We certainly believe that foods and beverages intended for human consumption should be subject to all the legislation and regulatory requirements that would make them fit for human consumption, and allow their recall if they fall short of that; but we believe that it is better, at least at this stage, to give the States the opportunity to get themselves organised and to put laws into place on a State by State basis . . .

The imposition of a sunset clause was designed to force the States to act more speedily on the matter of model food Acts. As we know, the hoped for uniform food recall legislation at State level has not eventuated. As Senator Haines indicated in 1986, in those circumstances the Australian Democrats will support the removal of the sunset clause. The Opposition's proposed amendment would continue the sunset clause. It was the Democrats' intention two years ago to give the States that time. Very little action has taken place, Western Australia and Queensland having acted. We have to take a stand now in the interests of the community as a whole. In health matters the Federal Government certainly has not only the right but also the obligation to act in a situation where the States have not done so. Certainly one agrees with the States' rights argument, a finely balanced argument, but the balance needs to be set against the rights of members of the wider community and their need for protection in this case. It is on that basis that the Democrats are going ahead, as we foreshadowed two years ago, with supporting this amendment.

It is worth reiterating briefly in this debate how important the product safety and product information provisions of part 5, division 1a, of the Act are and why their application to food and drink is so desirable. It is the desire of the Australian Democrats that the Federal Government introduce comprehensive regulations regarding food and drink labelling. I hope that the Minister will give this matter his urgent attention. Division 1a, which was inserted into the Act in 1986, provides for the banning of unsafe goods, the declaration of product safety and information, and the mandatory recall of hazardous foods. First, the 1986 amendments were necessary because earlier provisions had no application to unsafe product supply before a banning order was issued. Secondly, no powers were available to deal with the problem of unsafe products which had reached the hands of consumers. Thirdly, under the legislation adequate opportunity was not provided to review decisions taken by the Minister under the then sections 62 and 63.

We are all aware in our daily lives of the incidence of hazardous products-adulterated salami and the tragic disembowelling of a child by a swimming pool filter, to name just two. The pre-1986 position was clearly unsatisfactory. The insertion in 1986 remedied the situation by bringing in recall powers and powers to prevent the supply of unsafe products. Naturally, the Australian people expect the Commonwealth to be able to protect consumers nationally from unsafe consumer goods and it is pleasing that it has been able to do so since 1986 and that the provisions will now apply to food and drink as well, through the amendment in this Bill.

The last amendment contained in the Bill is essentially administrative in nature, resulting from the transfer of responsibility for the enforcement of part 5, division 1a, from the Trade Practices Commission to the Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs. The Australian Democrats have no quarrel with that and will be supporting the amendment.

I would like to make some comments about the general area of consumer affairs and specifically to address some of the issues raised by Senator Short in his contribution to this debate. Senator Short's complaint was, as I think he put it, about the politicisation of consumer affairs. I found his argument, in a sense, quite fascinating. It is flying in the face of reality to avoid any sort of politicisation in any public interest area, although I understand that Senator Short's concern about politicisation is one about party politicisation, but I would make it clear that activism in this area of community interest is a highly political exercise. I sometimes find it frustrating, when dealing with community groups, that they very often insist that they are not political. Of course they are. Obviously questions of party politicisation are a concern, but the arguments that Senator Short makes have a great many flaws. He is looking at only one side of the balance of power out there in the real world.

He complains, for instance, about the representational levels of the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO) and points out that by far its latest membership comes from the Australian Consumers Association (ACA), a group which has very wide membership throughout the community. I have been a member of the ACA for more years than I care to remember. I joined the ACA when I became a housewife. Having been a member-a very unpolitical member-way back then, long before the days of the Australian Democrats, on many occasions I have been grateful for the information provided to me. Even information for which I have had no personal use has been at the very least stimulating and thought provoking. If Senator Short is arguing against the provision of that kind of information to consumers and ordinary people in the community, I certainly cannot support his argument. He seems to be arguing against any contribution by government to the major consumer organisations in Australia. To do that with any balance, anybody in this debate would have to argue, there ought to be no government support, for instance, for the business sector.

What we are looking at in the whole area of consumer affairs and consumer representation is an achievement of some balance in a society in which our business and industry sector has enormous power by virtue of its position in our economy. Individual consumers can be totally lost in this sort of situation, and should not be. The development of a community sector which represents the voices of the community, of individual and ordinary consumers, should be welcomed. In any community organisation it will always be difficult to achieve total or perfect representation, and even to have all the activities of such an organisation perfect and unchallenge- able. But surely that is also the case on the other side of the coin, and it goes much too far to talk of these organisations as a sham.

Senator Short expressed sensitivity about an anti-business bias on behalf of the consumer affairs sector and even, I suggest, on behalf of consumers. One needs to be careful about accusing any individual or sector of being anti-business. If voices are raised against the activity of another sector in the community, particularly a sector like the business sector, which has enormous power and influence in our community because of its economic base, because of the fact that it is such a large and productive sector of our community, the fact that voices are raised against business at one time or another on one issue or another should be seen by business as a cautionary note. It should be taken by business as part of its responsibility to listen and to act where necessary. To believe otherwise is to say that we should still be driving cars which basically are unsafe, that we should still be prepared to put up with no regulation at all in the areas I have already mentioned in my speech; that we should take a risk with what we drink, eat, use or buy. That argument cannot be sustained.

Business can be very sensitive about regulation. I exhort Senator Short and any of his colleagues who share his views, if they really are concerned about business regulations, to support an Australian Democrat initiative which is coming up via Senator McLean, which is designed to cut red tape and regulation for small business as opposed to some of the corporate giants about the place. I confidently expect that Senator Short will exhort the Opposition seriously to look at that. Of course things can be overregulated, there is no question about it.

Senator Short was concerned about influence over public policy specifically in regard to groups such as AFCO and the ACA. If we want to talk about influence over public policy, we should look at a couple of other areas-not the consumer affairs area necessarily and some community based groups with government funding and a fairly wide membership, but the potential influence over public policy of the increasingly fewer number of media moguls about at the moment. I hope that Senator Short's concern about undue influence over public policy will be exercising his mind in the current debate in the Opposition coalition as to what it will do with the proposals to put more ability to influence public policy into fewer hands when it comes to television ownership, which is a very current issue. There is a need for balance.

I think that Senator Short was endeavouring to contribute to that point in his argument, but he takes the argument too far. He seems terribly concerned about radical social change at the hands of these consumer organisations. I would say that we have had some radical social change through consumer organisations and will continue to do so, but while that social change is occurring through the giving of information to ordinary consumers, by putting pressure where it should be duly put on decision makers relating to dissatisfaction with business products and industry, that change is necessary and defensible. Ordinary individuals in the community need to be able to make their own decisions and any legislation or organisation designed to enhance people's ability to do that gets the support of the Australian Democrats. But people must also be able to make those decisions when they possess information.

The consumer organisations and movement provide information to people in the community. That is necessary because the only other sort of so-called information that is available, apart from in the halls of academe, is what passes for information but is pushed down everybody's throat by way of advertisements. We all know that what we see in advertisements is all too often not information but promotion, propaganda, what the advertiser wants the community to know, think, feel and, more particularly, buy. There is a need for a counter to that sort of promotional exercise which is undertaken through advertising by business to entice consumers into buying products. If that is a legitimate exercise, so is the exercise of the provision of information of a more specific nature which may question some of the promotion by business or industry concerned.

It is taking the argument too far to suggest that the provision of this sort of information to people in the community should be condemned. It takes the argument too far to say that if organisations that attempt to do this are not totally representative of everybody in the community they should not exist. It is also taking the argument too far to say that the entire membership or leadership of an organisation such as this comprises members of the Australian Labor Party (ALP). If that were the case 12 months ago, I believe that it is far less likely to be the case now. What the Democrats are finding increasingly is that people such as those who have been members of the ALP in the past are not renewing their membership, and are actively contacting the Australian Democrats in the interests of the issues about which they are concerned, having felt very badly let down recently as the Government appears to be moving more and more in the direction of the top end of town and less and less in the direction of the ordinary people. They are clear messages which the Government has had in recent elections. I suggest that Senator Short's concerns about ALP membership of organisations such as these might be somewhat allayed by that kind of trend.

However, I wonder whether Senator Short is as concerned about the political leanings of people in other organisations representing other sorts of groups in the community. I have already mentioned small business. It would be interesting if we had some sort of breakdown of the party membership of the leadership at least of the Australian Small Business Association (ASBA). I did not hear Senator Short condemn that organisation for being in a position to have undue influence over public policy, for pushing for radical social change, or for being unrepresentative of the constituency that it claims to represent. I do not want to single out ASBA; I suggest that there are any number of business and industry organisations about which the same sort of accusation could be made. That is a fact of life. People make political decisions. They choose which side of politics they believe will push their interests further, and that is part of the political process.

There are some sensitive positions which would require that people do not have overt party membership. That is something we Democrats experience all too often. I suggest that officials in organisations lay themselves open to some criticism if they actively push a party line. I suggest that politically that is particularly debilitating. It is a pity if any community organisation closely aligns itself to any political party. What such organisations should be doing, and what increasingly those groups on the side of politics which are concerned for ordinary individuals in the community are doing, is casting around. In recent election campaigns we have heard from the Liberal Party claims to the allegiance of many of those ordinary Australians who feel let down by the Hawke Labor Government. It is not beyond canvassing support from those people; nor, I think, is any honest political party. We all put forward what it is that we have to offer. We are there in the marketplace for people in the community.

I make those few remarks on the general issue of consumer affairs in response specifically to some of the points raised by Senator Short. As I said, the Oppositions's proposed amendment will not receive our support. We have given the States two years to perform in this area. Given that Western Australia and Queensland have performed, people cannot even use the argument, which is often used in this place, that all the good States have done it; it is only those baddies that we are waiting on, and we had better not infringe people's States rights just because the States rights States will not perform. That is not the case in this regard. Clearly, the Democrats are interested in ensuring that all Australians, whichever State they live in, are protected in the way that this legislation will proceed to protect them. Therefore, the Democrats support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise briefly to speak to the amendments to the Trade Practices Act. The amendments are not particularly controversial. I wanted to make a contribution to the debate in an attempt to put them in context. I am putting them in the context of noting that the consumer protection provisions of the Trade Practices Act are not being used by private consumers. I note also that the Trade Practices Commission did not readily take up the provisions of the Act. When I asked why, and carried out an investigation, I found the answer was, firstly, largely related to cost-that is, consumers cannot afford to use the recourse of the law in this area. Secondly, they fail to understand what their rights are or how to enforce them, so there is a shortcoming in education. Thirdly, it seems that there is a lack of expertise in the professional legal world in this area largely because there is no market to warrant the development of that expertise-a dog chasing its tail argument.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the point, one might ask, in looking to further continual reform of the consumer protection provisions of the Act if, for other reasons beyond the draftsmanship of the provisions, the remedies will simply not be utilised by consumers? I will try to develop this argument a little further. In doing so I find it useful to refer to an article by Peter Cerexhe in Consuming Interest of March 1988. He expresses concerns under the heading `The Trade Practices Act: a farce for consumers'. He noted that a survey conducted by the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council indicated that, of 152 trade practices cases decided by the Federal Court between 1 July 1985 and 30 June 1987, only 13 were commenced by private consumers. Most cases were initiated by businesses using the consumer protection provisions of the Act against their competitors. This is a useful vehicle that we certainly do not condemn, but it was not the intention of the draftsmen in implementing these consumer protection laws in this Act.

Furthermore, he noted that the Trade Practices Commission was responsible for only 24 cases. That would indicate that the Trade Practices Commission also saw its principal responsibility in relation to other parts of the Act. That might also be a sound argument when looking at questions of resources and so forth. It indicates that if the consumer was to look to the Trade Practices Commission as the Government watchdog in this area, the Trade Practices Commission, for reasons, as I said, of resources or other priorities, would not meet that responsibility.

As I indicated, the reasons for this failure to utilise the provisions of the Act seem to be the three areas of cost, education and lack of expertise. Cost is fairly obvious. In consumer cases we are generally dealing with individuals who often do not have great resources. Their cases are likely to be against businesses-often multinationals-with enormous resources. One can readily see that the risk of entering into that litigation for a consumer who may well feel aggrieved in most just circumstances is, to that consumer, rarely warranted. The answer to that, one might immediately think, is that the consumer should seek the assistance of legal aid. However, the facts seem to be that very little legal aid in this nation is appropriated to the needs of consumers in this type of case. Why is that? It would seem that it is partly a prejudice, partly a view that these matters are not of great consequence and that moneys put aside by the public to assist those who are not able to fund their litigation would be better spent in areas of criminal law, matrimonial cases, running down matters, or other types of law. Certainly the facts seem to indicate that very little legal aid funding is appropriated in the causes of consumer actions.

It is the argument of Mr Cerexhe that there is a prejudice of judges against these actions-partly, I guess, because of pressures on them. The natural tendency is to look upon matters of greater importance as being those involving much larger sums of money. There is a tendency, therefore, for what might be described as the small case to be pushed down the list or pushed down to lower courts. Mr Cerexhe, in his article, gives specific examples of judges in the Federal Court who find these cases before them regarding them as being more appropriately dealt with before a registrar. This fails to appreciate that to that individual consumer his action, which may not involve a large sum of money, is just as important as another case, involving for example, the Coles-Myer group, and a much larger sum of money. The tendency is to regard the latter as of greater importance.

It is very difficult to try to calculate in any accurate terms what percentage of legal aid is available for this cause. I say to the Minister that when he looks at breaking down the functions of the administration of the Australian Legal Aid Office in the future he might look to a category that involves consumer protection because at the moment it does not exist and therefore in absolute terms we are unable to say what sum is utilised in this way. All evidence that is available through the consumer organisations would suggest that very little is utilised. It is also interesting when one looks at the provision that exists in the Act that allows the Attorney-General to give assistance. We find-at least if we take the advice of Professor Goldring-that as far as he has been able to determine no assistance has been granted under this section in the case of contravention of part V, division 1 of the Act. Therefore, there seems to be little assistance available from the public purse for consumers to gain assistance in prosecutions of these claims.

There is the concern of the small consumer that the action may well become a test case, as is often the case in relation to these matters, and therefore what he might regard as a simple dispute between himself and, say, a manufacturer suddenly becomes a matter of enormous consequence to the manufacturer. Not surprisingly, therefore, that manufacturer, recognising the chance of a test case, will put great resources into defeating the claim. What is the answer? The answer is obviously that the Minister and the Government should recognise that to consumers their actions, although they may not involve large sums of money, can be just as important under this head of action in part V of the Trade Practices Act as are cases in many other categories. Legal aid should be treated in that light. In the longer term class actions might be of some assistance. I note that we can now expect the report of the Australian Law Reform Commission on class actions finally to come down in July this year. I think the wait has been nearly a decade. It will be interesting to see whether that report will also, in some way, be able to assist consumers in certain circumstances to overcome this cost impairment to using the remedies available under the Act.

The second area of failure would appear to be that of education. Consumers still do not realise-although this Act has now been in force for some considerable time-the provisions of the Act that offer them protection in this area. They still do not understand their rights in this area and, furthermore, do not know how to enforce them. That also came out in Mr Cerexhe's article and seems to be widely accepted. It therefore places on all of us-in the Parliament and elsewhere, not only the consumer organisations-a responsibility to ensure that members of the public are made aware of their rights under legislation that we have passed and their capacity to enforce those rights.

As to the third area in which Mr Cerexhe sees a failure occurring, when a consumer does have an action under the provisions of this Act, very often he finds that there are not experts available in the community to take the action on his behalf. I guess that the answer again comes in the form of education. Perhaps the reason has been, as I indicated earlier, that the Act-even the consumer protection provisions-has tended to be used in a predominantly commercial way rather than in a consumer protection way. I note that the Minister, in a Press release on World Consumer Rights Day on 15 March, stated:
. . . I will ensure that everything is done to make sure that low income earners and welfare benefit recipients have equal and easy access to consumer rights and redress mechanisms.

I remind the Minister of that, with great respect. It would seem to me, certainly on the basis of my research, that that does not exist at the moment and therefore I urge the Minister to meet his own rhetoric with action. I note that we now have a Federal Bureau of Consumer Affairs in this area and that it is now employing 26 staff. I suggest that the time of members of this staff could well be served not only in looking at further ways of changing the law, but also in looking at ways in which the public can be made more aware of the law and given the resources to enforce their provisions under the law.

In these general comments on the weaknesses of the practical application of the consumer credit provisions, I must also mention the problem that is obvious to anyone who attempts to study this area: the fact that it comprises at the moment a myriad of different provisions at both State and Federal levels. Many of them are inconsistent, many are confusing and many offer different remedies. When we have the law in this state of confusion it is not surprising that the innocent consumer who was to be protected by it has difficulty in finding his way through these provisions of protection. It is obvious that something needs to be done about this confusion. I note the argument that it has come about largely because of the tenuous constitutionality of the Commonwealth provisions and, therefore, the feeling that they need to be supported by State legislation; nevertheless, this maze of Federal and State pieces of legislation is not putting together law that can serve the consumer as it should. I notice that the Constitutional Commission has been giving some consideration to this matter. I hope that we will at least in turn give consideration to its recommendation. I think its recommendation has been that section 51 of the Constitution should be amended to include protection of consumers and their interests as a concurrent power of the Commonwealth and the States.

Having made those general comments about what I see as a failure of the system, I nevertheless recognise that the three specific amendments before the Senate today are necessary-two of them absolutely necessary. In the case of the third amendment we have an alternative way of doing it but, nevertheless, a change must be made. The first amendment concerns the provision relating to false representations. In Chaudhary's case it was said that this did not apply to value. Obviously, that required a small and simple amendment to section 53 of the Act, which is before us and has the support, as Senator Short said, of the Opposition.

I note that the second amendment requires the removal of a sunset clause put in by the Senate which dealt with food and drink for human consumption as part of the general provision that covered the banning of unsafe goods. If that sunset clause is not removed now, food and drink included for human consumption would not be included. We on this side of the chamber have said: why not extend the sunset clause for a further two years to allow the States to implement uniform laws? I can only say that whilst that remains our preference-that is, a preference for consumer laws at a level of government closer to the people than is the Federal Parliament-one must note that the States have not implemented this law during the period that was allowed by the Parliament. I note that only two jurisdictions-Queensland and Western Australia-have made the necessary regulations to require the recall of foods, and even they have not done it in a uniform manner. Certainly, coming from the State of South Australia, which has been proud of its contribution to consumer protection law, I for one will go back and inquire as to why South Australia has been inactive in meeting its responsibility. But, certainly, if the States are not going to meet a responsibility that is obvious, the Commonwealth must step into the breach. Although we have a preference for doing it in a different way, we recognise that something needs to be done today.

The third amendment concerns the question of enforcement and is really an internal procedural matter that is necessary for efficient enforcement by the Federal Bureau. Looking at the record of the Trade Practices Commission in the enforcement of constitutional matters, which I mentioned earlier, it would seem to me that a strong argument has been developed for moving this function to the Federal Bureau. Therefore we support this small amendment, which will allow the more efficient utilisation of the provisions by the Bureau.

In summary, I support the tenor of the amendments. But I repeat that these amendments are going to be of little use if, notwithstanding the legislation, consumers find that because of cost, a lack of understanding or a lack of expertise in professional circles they are not able to take advantage of the benefits of the protections that we afford them under this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to respond to the arguments put in this debate by both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. At the outset I wish to place on record my acknowledgment of the constructive way in which the Australian Democrats have played this piece of legislation and also the way in which the Liberal Party has acknowledged the necessity for at least two of the three points that the Government seeks to address with the Trade Practices Amendment Bill 1988. However, I wish to respond to some of the points made in the debate by Opposition speakers on the second issue, that of course being the food provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Before doing so I want to acknowledge the way Opposition speakers have handled this debate. On the one hand, I think Senator Hill approached it with a great degree of intelligence and maturity, acknowledging the problems along the way, and made some constructive comments and analysis, some of which I will go back to at a later time. On the other hand, I think Senator Short reacted in a manner indicative of the way that not only the consumer advocacy world but also industry seem to have lost contact with the Liberal Party. His contribution as official spokesperson in this place and Mr Moore's contributions in the House of Representatives are indicative that the will of not only the community but also industry has managed to leave the Liberal Party behind.

Let me make a couple of points in general about consumerism and consumer advocacy and the role of the respective parties in this Parliament. I think Senator Short laid claim to Liberal purity and support for consumer advocacy. I remind Senator Short that it was in 1974 that consumer protection provisions were first placed in the Trade Practices Act. In fact, they were opposed at that stage by the shadow Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott. I remind honourable senators also that in 1975, when the Federal Labor Government intended to introduce comprehensive legislation to cover consumer affairs, that was very strenuously opposed by the present Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard. I also remind honourable senators that the rhetoric has not changed and that in 1985, when we were dealing with hazardous product recalls, the Opposition once again opposed a very effective and important measure to protect consumers. I remind honourable senators of the rhetoric of Mr Moore, the shadow spokesperson in the House of Representatives, who said, `The marketplace on the whole can provide the best for consumers'.

Senator Short may have had a couple of initiatives along the way, but I think on the whole that when one looks at the substantive record and at the rhetoric of the Opposition at the moment one does not have to get emotive and call it an affront to intelligence, as some speakers did in the House of Representatives. It is fixed very much in an ideology which does not share much with reality. The approach seems to be to deregulate at any cost, because deregulation provides benefits to consumers. But it is not a left wing position to argue to the contrary. I quote the following editorial from the Financial Times of 31 January 1986. The last paragraph refers to the deregulation debate in the United Kingdom and states:

. . . there is a vital and probably permanent role for regulatory policy. As policymakers in both the US and Britain are already finding, they cannot just set rules designed to let competition flourish and then stand back. They also need to be ready to intervene to keep markets open.

One needs only to look at the history of food legislation and this provision to see what would have happened if the Opposition's position had been carried in 1986. Since that time there have been 10 product recalls. Let me cite one example. In November 1986 baby food was recalled under this specific legislation because of its poisoning effect. I could go through a list of contaminated food, ranging from ricotta cheese to brown sugar, desiccated coconut and canned tuna-all products recalled because of effective Federal legislation.

In terms of being out of touch with reality, let me also look at this argument that the Federal Government is making a grab for power in the States. What we are talking about with this initiative is a situation where the Federal Government exercises a reserve power. There is still power in the States to pursue food law, so long as it is not directly inconsistent with Federal legislation. But, more importantly, we have over recent years set up a system of food law regulation which has the degree of uniformity that the consumer deserves and industry wants. We have set up a Uniform Food Law Interpretation Committee, whose role is to set standards for food laws. That is a State and Federal body which will operate under the provisions which Senator Short threw a big question mark over. Not only is the setting of food standards going to be approached in a cooperative way, but also the enforcement of them will be pursued in a cooperative way with the agreement of and with the mechanism set up with the States. The States and the Federal Government recognise that we are talking about a national market and national producers. We are talking about companies that produce items that cross State boundaries. If Senator Short were to spend some time talking to some portions of industry that he has not spoken to so far, he would get a very strong push to do even more than what this Government is doing. Industry is concerned that it has to conform to different laws in different States and to different sets of standards. The greatest degree of uniformity is the most desirable for industry. I think a consultative process with industry groups would be quite beneficial to the Opposition and the contribution it could make to better government in this country.

But that is not the end of the argument. On the one hand, the Government and I are criticised for a grab for power. On the other hand, the same people who do that put out Press statements saying that the Federal Government does not act strongly enough in the interests of consumers. I refer honourable senators to what Mr John Moore, the shadow Minister for business and consumer affairs, said on the issue of flammable foam in furniture, such as beds that can explode because of their high content of particular chemical ingredients. On 17 March Mr Moore criticised me for not acting quickly enough and for not regulating the use of flammable foam. He wanted a national response in that area. He wanted the exercise of national legislation. But is it not contradictory and hypocritical that, on the one hand, he says to the Federal Government, `Act quickly, without any consultation with industry or the States, and regulate the use of flammable foam' and, on the other hand, he says, `We do not really see a role for you in the setting of food standards'?

I think this contradiction is highlighted even more when we look at some foods. The Opposition is questioning the Government's role in the setting of national food standards. We are told that it is the State's role. But dog food is not food. The Opposition's approach, which acknowledges product safety but not food safety as being the role of the Federal Government, is that the Federal Government can intervene to legislate to protect dogs in their consumption habits, but not human beings. I think that very starkly illustrates the sorts of problems that fixed ideology causes the Opposition in this place. Even if we did not have Federal food laws and we left it all to the States, with the national market, with the mobility of food and consumers, there would still be a need for national food legislation to cover situations where food crosses borders and where some States will not have the constitutional power to cover it.

Senator Short went on to make a point about appointments made by the Federal Government in the consumer protection area. Let me make it very clear that people are appointed by me and by this Government not because of any affiliation with the Australian Federation of Consumer Organisations (AFCO)-although in some instances they are-but more often than not because of the contribution that they make to the general interests of consumers in this country.

Senator Short questioned appointments because of their political bias and this close interrelationship with AFCO. I direct Senator Short's attention to the National Consumer Affairs Advisory Council. Without going through all the members-of course, if he wishes me to incorporate the list I will do so-the Council has 15 members, including someone who was the Consumer Relations Manager for Kraft Foods Ltd; someone who was a vice-president of the Queensland Bar Association; someone who was a Director of University Carpet Wholesalers Pty Ltd in Sydney; a person who was Deputy Chairman of Television Broadcasters Ltd and is a retiring member of the Advisory Board of the Business Studies Unit, University of Adelaide; a person who was a quality controller with K Mart (Australia) Ltd; and someone who was the Chairman of Grace Bros Pty Ltd; and Director of Standard Telephones and Cables Pty Ltd; and the list goes on. If Senator Short is to be fair about this and if his criticism is to have any value at all, it needs to be balanced. I think that Senator Short has done himself a disservice by picking on one part of the Government's representative selection process and not the other.

Senator Short then went on to make a very general attack on advocacy groups-AFCO and the Australian Consumers Association (ACA). Those groups play a very important role, especially in the context of the debate pursued by Senator Hill when he recognised the powerlessness of consumers to pursue a remedy under the current legal system. The Government acknowledges that those groups play a very important role; it does not always agree with them, but their role is vital for the protection of consumers in this country. The ACA has a membership and circulation list of over 200,000 people and, in fact, it is more representative than the Liberal Party of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not a membership. They are not members; they are subscribers to Choice. What voting rights do they have in the ACA? They have none at all.

—I will come to that. I draw the comparison between the ACA and the Federal Liberal Party one step further and pick up a point made by Senator Powell: What sort of representative rights do members of the Liberal Party have at Federal Executive and Federal Council level? In respect of the specific questions raised about ACA and AFCO, to the extent that they come within my responsibility, I will respond; and I am sure that the Minister for Science, Customs and Small Business (Mr Barry Jones) will respond in respect of the extent that they come within his responsibility. I am informed that, in terms of the research work conducted for the Australian Customs Service, no such paid work is undertaken by AFCO. I will leave these questions on notice and come back to them.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short then proceeded to attack Alan Asher for some general political involvement. Perhaps it is a reflection of my state of ignorance of politics, but I do not know Alan Asher's political involvement. He was appointed to the Trade Practices Commission (TPC) not because of any political involvement but because of his long and well-respected history in protecting consumers and pursuing their interests. Bodies such as the TPC have the important role of protecting consumers, and that is acknowledged.

Senator Short then went on to attack AFCO for its close links with the ALP Federal parliamentary Caucus. Let me place on record my acknowledgment and support for the work done by the Caucus committee on consumer affairs. I have been present from time to time when AFCO members have been in attendance, as have industry and consumer representatives. It is a very energetic and hard-working committee which conducts consultations throughout the country in both city and rural areas. It would be totally incongruous if AFCO was not one of the groups with which that committee had consultations.

I turn now to some of the problems raised by Senator Hill, and I will do so in the spirit in which they were presented. Senator Hill raised the problem that consumers were not using the provisions of the Trade Practices Act in any substantial way. There are a number of responses I could and should make to that. First of all, the Government's approach to trade practices and consumer protection provisions is not to drag into court every retailer, manufacturer or distributor who breaches the Act; it is a consultative approach. The TPC has continuing discussions with, and information channels to, industry, and on the whole we see the provisions as very much setting standards of conduct in industry; and on the whole industry has complied with them. Just because only a small number of people sue for tort does not mean that they are not aware of their obligations under tort law, and that is very much the situation under consumer protection legislation.

We also recognise that the provisions may not be used by individual consumers as much as we would like. As a consequence, in recent days we have taken steps to introduce representative actions to allow for the cross-vesting of legislation to allow consumers to initiate actions in lower courts. In response to Senator Hill's last comment, I point out that the Australian Law Reform Commission is in fact looking at class actions. I also put it to Senator Hill that not all actions under the Trade Practices Act are pursued in the Federal Court. Most consumers are concerned about warranties and many actions are commenced in State small claim tribunals in pursuance of consumer rights under the Trade Practices Act.

Let me make one final point: the Australian Government sees consumer protection as very much part of our social justice approach to government. We acknowledge the need to protect consumers and their rights and to ensure that those rights are effectively pursued. We do this in the context of acknowledging the need for greater deregulation, and in that context we also acknowledge a need for regulation which is effective, uniform and streamlined to ensure that the principle of caveat emptor, which some of those opposite want us to go back to, does not dominate the marketplace. We acknowledge the need for greater participation of consumers, consumer representatives and government in these decision-making processes, and we also acknowledge the need for greater uniformity in Australia, not only because of the interests of consumers but also because of the interests of industry.

I congratulate Senator Hill for noting that the Constitutional Commission at least has acknowledged the need for broader Commonwealth power in the area of consumer protection. Of course, in this respect he disagrees with his colleagues, but he shows the constructive way that government in this country should be approaching issues such as this, and of course that indicates why someone with Senator Hill's talent is ignored by an excessively cynical and pragmatic Opposition. In closing, I thank the Australian Democrats and the Liberal Party for supporting two of these three measures.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
