SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have circulated on behalf of the Opposition an amendment to clause 4. It proposes the repeal of section 65u of the principal Act, which, as we discussed during the second reading debate, is the sunset clause. If existing section 65u is not altered, part V, division 1a of the Trade Practices Act would have no application as from 1 July this year, which is just a couple of months hence. As I said during the second reading debate, we share the Government's wish not to have from 1 July a situation where this part of the Act does not apply.

SPEECH.PARA: However, unlike the Government, we believe that the States should be given an extension of time for the introduction of legislation to mirror the Federal Act. This has not happened, despite the hopes that we had when the sunset clause was inserted in 1986 on the proposition of the Australian Democrats. When proposing the sunset clause amendment Senator Haines said:

The intention of this amendment is to give the industry time in which to pressure the States into introducing consumer protection legislation in the area of food and drink supply and sale which is uniform and which incorporates all the requirements contained in the Federal trade practices legislation before us.

As yet that has not happened. Only two States, Queensland and Western Australia, have introduced regulations or taken action to implement that intent; the other four States have not done that. I think that is a matter for regret. In commenting on Senator Bolkus's response when winding up the second reading debate, let me say that it is not the view of the Opposition that there should not be uniformity of laws across Australia in this area. We agree with what Senator Bolkus said about the desirability and need for uniformity. What we are talking about is whether that uniformity can be achieved by the States introducing uniform legislation, mirror legislation, or whether it can be done just by Federal government legislation-which, of course, amongst other things, would involve major constitutional problems.

So there is no difference, I believe, between the Government and the Opposition in relation to the end objective, but what we do wish to see and give every opportunity to happen is the end objective achieved by the introduction of uniform legislation by the States. It is indicated in the Government's explanatory memorandum to the Bill that the intention to have uniform legislation brought in by the States has not been realised. That is certainly true. The explanatory memorandum then says, `. . . nor is it likely to be in the foreseeable future'. The Opposition does not know whether that is the case; it is an assertion that we would like to see tested by an extension of the existing sunset clause for a further two years.

I agree that it has already taken the States many years even to focus on this issue, and it is a matter for regret that the States have not taken action to introduce legislation in the two years since the sunset clause was inserted. However, the Opposition would like to see such an extension. With the Minister's persuasive powers amongst his Labor colleagues throughout Australia, I am sure that we are looking to him to exercise his responsibility to encourage the States to adopt the very legislation that we are talking about. Of the States involved, of course, Victoria and South Australia are Labor States; New South Wales has just changed political hands and I am not sure--

TALK.START.PARA: —For the better.

—For the better, of course. After 12 years of neglect and disregard in New South Wales we now have a government that is prepared to act in the interests of that State and its people. I have not had the opportunity to discuss with the incoming Liberal Party and National Party Government in New South Wales its attitude towards this matter. However, the very fact that there has been a change of government is one reason, I believe, for an extension of this sunset clause. It would also give the Federal Government the opportunity once more, together with industry-and I stress that-to encourage and pressure the States to take the necessary action that we all desire.

SPEECH.PARA: If at the end of a further extension of time that has not happened, a decision on the matter will have to be made at that time. But we would press the Government to accept the view that, whilst it is understandable that it may feel that two years has been enough time to try to get the States to act, it should use its influence, in conjunction with the industry, to achieve the result that we all regard as being preferable. It is for those reasons that I move on behalf of the Opposition this amendment for an extension of the sunset clause for two years until 1 July 1990. I have just outlined some of my reasons and I outlined other reasons during the second reading debate. I move:
Page 2, clause 4, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Extension of section 65U
``4. Section 65U of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section is substituted:
Cessation of Division in respect of food and drinks
`65U. On 1 July 1990 this Division shall cease to have effect in respect of goods which are foods and drinks intended for human consumption.'.''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill 1987, the purpose of which is to amend the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act 1972 to implement changes in a variety of areas dealing with promotions, transfers, appeals, forfeiture of office and attachment of salary, basically in the same way as the Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Act 1986 did for the Public Service Act. One of the most attractive aspects of the Bill is that the definition of `efficiency' is brought into line with that in the Public Service Act. This means that seniority has been abolished as a basis for promotion or transfer and efficiency is the only criterion that will be taken into account. Of particular interest is the fact that efficiency includes the potential of the applicant for further career development in the Public Service and the ability of each officer to perform the duties of other positions of the same or equal classification. The coalition regards that as a very positive move for the Commonwealth Teaching Service and supports that aspect of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: A further attractive aspect of the Bill is that the appeals procedure is substantially streamlined. The first point I wish to make in that respect is that appeals can be made only by people who applied for the position in the first place. Of course, this seems a very commonsense amendment and one wonders why we have taken so long to get there. Commonsense in this regard should perhaps be referred to as uncommon sense; it seems ridiculous that someone who did not apply for the position in the first place should be able to hold up the process of appointment, et cetera, by appealing. The second provision for the streamlining of appeals is that where the selection was made other than by a joint selection panel someone can appeal but if the selection is made by a panel the person cannot.

It is in terms of the panels that the coalition has some concern. I will get to those in a minute. The joint selection panels are made up of a chairman appointed by the Minister and two or three other people appointed by the relevant authority. Those other people cannot serve unless the relevant staff organisation agrees with their appointment. There is something of a technical contrast here between the Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Act and the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill. Under the former, the Merit Protection Agency appoints the chairman or convener of a panel, the Secretary to the department has a nominee and the staff association has a nominee. As I understand it, the Merit Protection Agency has no power with respect to the Commonwealth Teaching Service so the Minister makes the appointment of the convener, who may well come from the Merit Protection Agency.

While the relevant authority cannot appoint someone whom the staff association disapproves of, as the Secretary to a department can, I am told that if this Bill is passed in its existing form the procedure outlined would simply reflect the existing practice. The Government's approach has been that it is better to have a more conciliatory system of industrial relations within the Commonwealth Teaching Service and that it would be more efficient and conducive to harmonious industrial relations if, instead of the equivalent of the Secretary having a nominee and the staff organisation having a nominee, two or three nominees were appointed where both parties agreed that they were suitable appointees. Expressed in that way it does seem commonsense. In formulating the legislation to reflect what I am told is existing practice, the Government has given the staff associations effectively a right of veto over appointments to the joint selection panels because if they do not like someone they simply do not agree, and someone cannot be appointed unless it is with their agreement.

The coalition asks: If this simply reflects existing practice-it would be a good sign if it did; if the staff association and the Minister could agree and were consistently agreeing-and it is not designed or intended to give the relevant staff association a power of veto and that would not happen in practice, what is the matter with removing the clause which effectively gives a right to veto? Given that it is existing practice it could proceed as we are told it is now, namely, in a harmonious fashion, and the appointments could be made by agreement if that is what the parties want. So we see circulated amendments Nos 1 to 3 as achieving just that, giving the opportunity for the Minister to make appointments to the joint selection panels in agreement with the unions but without a right of union veto. They seem most appropriate amendments to make.

I understand that the Australian Democrats have an amendment in this regard which basically simply puts into other words that the appointments ought to be by agreement. The coalition will not accept the Democrats' amendment because all that it requires is for the relevant staff association publicly to say that it does not agree with the appointment of any particular person to the joint selection committee or panel and that makes it abundantly obvious that it is not in agreement and there is still an effective power of veto for the unions. All they have to do is to state publicly that they are not satisfied with the appointments and the Minister would have to change them. We think it is much more appropriate to leave the responsibility for selecting the panels and for taking all appropriate matters into account, including the need for agreement, with the Minister. So if the Minister chooses to make appointments that the union disagrees with it will be on the Minister's head and the Minister's achievements in industrial relations in that area will be the worse for having proceeded in that way. But that is where the responsibility should lie rather than the union having the veto power.

The other amendment that we will move in the committee stage is listed as No. 4 on the circulated amendments. It seeks to spell out even further our views with respect to union membership. It is in two parts. Firstly, it inserts a clause indicating that a joint selection committee would not be able to refuse to consider an application on the basis that the applicant was not a member of a relevant staff organisation. The second part of the amendment would ensure that a joint selection committee or a member of it would not, in assessing the claim of an applicant in accordance with the relevant section, take into consideration whether the applicant was a member of that union. The coalition will move those two parts together as amendment No. 4 in the committee stage.

The Bill deals with a number of other areas. Apparently, the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act 1972 was inadequate to deal with the arrangements for forfeiture of office by persons who did not show up at work. That inadequacy is catered for in this Bill. The Bill also deals with the question of transfers. Transfers have been required as a consequence of restructuring within the Australian Capital Territory. The Bill will allow people in the Commonwealth Teaching Service to be transferred to an institute of technical and further education. The Bill also puts the arrangements for attachment of salaries in line with the Public Service Act.

There is one matter, minor as it may seem, on which I would appreciate some comment from the Minister. The only apparent difference between the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill and the Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Act is the greater penalty under the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill, of $1,000 or six months gaol, as opposed to $100 or three months in the Public Service Act, for the offence committed when a creditor fails to notify the paying officer that the debt has been paid. This may seem a minor point, but, for the same offence, one wonders why the financial penalty is 10 times greater in the Bill and the alternative gaol penalty twice as long.

The coalition will support this Bill-even if the amendments are not agreed to by this chamber. However, I would be grateful if Senator Jenkins, in her speech, would detail for the chamber on what basis the Democrats feel they could not support our first, second and third amendments. Without going into detail, I remind honourable senators that those amendments remove the power of veto of joint selection committees from the relevant staff organisation and put the full responsibility for achieving harmonious industrial relations in that regard with the Minister. I look forward to hearing Senator Jenkins's comments in that regard

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In my speech on the Commonwealth Teaching Service Amendment Bill I certainly will address the issues to which Senator Vanstone referred. I do not have a copy of the Opposition amendments, but I presume that they are the same amendments as were put forward in the House of Representatives.
—Yes.

—As stated, the purpose of this Bill is to amend the Commonwealth Teaching Service Act 1972. The principal amendments bring the Act into line with the Public Service Act, which we applaud, in the areas of promotions, transfers, appeals, forfeitures of office and attachment of salary. Provision is also made for the transfer of staff from the Commonwealth Teaching Service (CTS) to certain Commonwealth authorities should it prove necessary, and I am sure that it will prove necessary, given the changes that are going on in the Australian Capital Territory schools and technical and further education (TAFE) sector. The Bill also provides for the implementation of certain technical changes to remove inconsistencies from the Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1972 Commonwealth Teaching Service Act has been amended a number of times, during the Whitlam, Fraser and Hawke governments. The amendments contained in this Bill are welcomed by the Australian Democrats. Our only argument with the Government is with the wording of clause 32 (2), which, in the opinion of the Australian Democrats, does not faithfully reflect the actual situation. I will address this matter in detail later. Clause 3 (b) contains additional definitions, including a definition of `relevant staff organisation'. `Relevant staff organisation', in relation to a position, means an organisation that is registered under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act 1904 and for membership of which a person holding the position would be eligible. That point is relevant to the clause in question, about which there will be some debate.

Clause 5 alters the definition of `efficiency' used by the selection panels in the initial selection of an officer and in appeals against selections to conform to the formula contained in the Public Service Act. At the same time, seniority is abolished as a factor for consideration in promotions and transfers, leaving efficiency as the sole determinant. The Australian Democrats also welcome this provision.

Clause 6 limits appeals to those persons who have applied for an advertised position-also a welcomed amendment. I agree with Senator Vanstone that it is totally ludicrous that people who have not even applied for a position in the first instance should be able to waste time and money putting forward an appeal-and appeals do take both time and money. This tightening is welcomed by the Australian Democrats.

Clause 7 inserts a new division 4 in the Bill. The provisions relating to the joint selection committees in this new division do not introduce any fundamentally new principle not already passed by the Parliament in the Public Service Legislation (Streamlining) Act 1986. I do not know what the coalition's position was on that issue but I suspect that it supported it. Under the new division 4 a relevant authority has the option of selecting officers on the advice of a joint selection committee. The recommendation of a committee, if accepted, is not subject to appeal. There will probably be debate on this point in the committee stage.

The joint selection committees represent, for management and staff associations, the option-and it is an option-for promotion selection in which the existing statutory appeal right is forgone. Therefore, it is critically important that the constitutions of these selection committees are credible and agreed to by all parties. In this case the relevant authority would be the Chief Education Officer of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority, or the yet to be appointed directors of the new Australian Capital Territory Institute of Technical and Further Education and Canberra Institute of the Arts. As I said, the process can occur only with the agreement of the involved parties. If such agreement is not reached, the usual procedures for promotion selection, which involve appeals procedures, are followed. The system is not disrupted in the event of the parties not being able to reach agreement. If agreement is not reached, the applicant goes through the appeals procedure.

In the Public Service reform legislation both management and staff associations have separate representatives on the joint selection panels. If either party does not wish joint selection to occur, it simply does not nominate representatives. This is not seen as the exercise of either a management or a union veto which grinds the selection process to a halt. Rather, it is the application of a legitimate preference by either party for joint selection or the standard promotion process. In practice, I have been told, there have been few joint selection committees, if any, operating in the main body of the Public Service, because the staff associations are most reluctant to forgo, on behalf of their members, the right of appeal. Accordingly, the benefits of the joint selection process are not being experienced in any significant way.

In the Commonwealth Teaching Service, I have been informed, a de facto system of joint selection has been operating for many years. The proposal now before the Parliament formalises this practice, which is considered by all parties to be credible and efficient. The difference from the Public Service reform legislation is that both parties in the Commonwealth Teaching Service wish to agree jointly on the total composition of any joint selection committee, except for the chairperson, who is appointed by the Minister. The Australian Democrats' amendment makes this absolutely clear. In other words, we also do not like the way in which the clause is set out in the Bill. To our minds, it is a veto clause. We prefer to see such wording as to make it absolutely clear that the formulation of a selection committee would be by agreement. Our suggested amendment is that the person shall not be appointed under paragraph (1) (b) unless the relevant authority and the relevant staff organisation have first agreed that the person is suitable for appointment. I have been informed that in fact this is what has been happening for some time; it has been a form of practice. This situation is seen as a far better one than that in the Public Service reform legislation, which polarises the joint selection committee into two major camps-that is, management and staff association. The method proposed in the legislation is based on a true industrial democracy style, which is applauded by the Australian Democrats.

In practice, the Commonwealth Teaching Service parties have had no difficulty in reaching agreement on mutually acceptable members of joint selection committees. However, because the CTS Act has not been amended, the statutory right of appeal still remains. This means that, besides the exhaustive inquiries which are made in selecting persons for promotion, the system also has to meet additional expenses associated with running an appeals system; and this can involve many thousands of dollars. In the school and TAFE systems, it is estimated, the immediate benefit by way of saving of public money is in the vicinity of $175,000, that is, the equivalent of six full time teaching positions. I would add, as someone who comes from the TAFE system in Western Australia, that in that State there is no system of selection panels and all appointments are subject to appeal. Everybody appeals, whoever is appointed, and I know full well that the system is costly and time-consuming and that much precious time is wasted in this way, although one would never want to remove the right to appeal where this is felt to be appropriate.

I turn to the Liberals' amendment. I understand that it seeks to change the method of appointment of joint selection committees such that only consultation will occur with the relevant staff association. We cannot agree with that because we feel that that the full composition of the committee should be by mutual agreement on both sides. Rather than management consulting with staff associations, we prefer to go for the mutual agreement-true industrial democracy. I cannot imagine why any staff association would want to forgo the right of a statutory appeal for its members if it were only to be consulted on the composition of a joint selection committee. In effect, the Liberal amendment could render the joint selection useless and could deny the ACT schools system the benefits to which I referred earlier.

I turn to division 5 of the Bill. This allows a relevant authority to retire an officer who has been absent on unauthorised leave for an extended period. It seems incredible that the matter has not been addressed before and it is a sensible amendment. However, in regard to 5a, which provides for a proportion of an officer's salary to be paid to a creditor where judgment is given against the officer by a court, I look forward to hearing further details from the Minister.

The Bill also contains a proposed new section 50a. The Government has stated that it proposes to consult with employee representatives about applicable conditions before staff are transferred under the proposed new section 50a. As this consultation is not included specifically within this legislation, I assure the Minister that the Australian Democrats will closely monitor these transfers between the various areas of education within the Commonwealth Teaching Service. This matter is of particular concern to teachers and lecturers in the Australian Capital Territory. That concludes my remarks in this second reading debate, but I feel that we shall need to spend more time at the committee stage on the clause which is at present subject to three amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to address my remarks during this debate on matters of public interest to a few taxation matters and anomalies that have arisen. On 10 December 1987, and again on 24 February 1988, I raised in the Senate the subject of lifting the provisional tax threshold-in other words, the figure at which unearned income would qualify for provisional tax-which has been sitting at $999 per year for at least the last nine years. That threshold has netted the savings of many young people and pensioners. I have just read an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 20 April 1988 which included these references to the Treasurer (Mr Keating):

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government is ready to increase the tax-free threshold on pensions in the May economic statement . . . and is considering altering provisional tax arrangements affecting pensioner earnings from savings and investments.

He said that he would like to announce increases in the pension tax threshold together with provisional tax adjustment provisions. I applaud him for those statements. With regard to the lifting of the provisional tax threshold, it seems to me from this statement-that is, that the Treasurer is considering increasing that threshold from $999 of unearned income to whatever figure he is thinking of-that he is thinking of increasing it only in the case of pensioners. This would be discriminatory. We have to look at the other end of the scale-young people trying to save for a home, as I have said before, or people who are just generally saving. When their unearned income reaches that figure of $999-or whatever figure the Treasurer decides on-they could be getting into that bracket. If he does not alter the $999 provision for anyone except pensioners, anyone with savings of $6,000 or $7,000 would be caught in the provisional tax net. In relation to people's savings, accountants time and time again say to both young and old people who have not paid provisional tax, `Now you will have to pay it'. They say, `What's this provisional tax bit? I had better spend some money and make sure that I do not pay provisional tax'. That is the context in which I raise this matter. I ask the Government, when it is considering whether, in the May economic statement, to increase the provisional tax threshold, to apply it across-the-board and not just to pensioners. I am sure that some such move will be made.

I would now like to move onto a different matter; that is, the taxing of share profits under section 26aaa of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I will quote a brief passage in a letter to me from the Taxpayers Association of Western Australia. I will quote straight from the letter:

The Perth office have indicated that they are sympathetic to the view that short term speculative losses should be allowed as a deduction however, although they have had continuous liaison with Canberra, their efforts have been unsuccessful.

We understand that the Taxation Office are shortly to issue assessments to taxpayers whereby profits on disposal of property within 12 months are assessed under Section 26aaa and losses on disposal of property-
which includes shares-
within 12 months are treated as a capital loss.

Take the simple example of a person on fairly average wages-a clerk somewhere, or a truck driver, a miner or something like that-of around $25,000. Under the pay as you earn (PAYE) system he is up for $6,682. But what if he made a $30,000 profit on one share transaction. Let us say he had a couple of thousand dollars to invest just before the share boom last year. A lot of people, working at the mines or in solicitors' and accountants' offices, got the bug and if they got on to a good issue they could quite easily have made such a profit-and I know some who did, although I am using the figure of $30,000 to make it easier. So this person bought these shares and then made a $30,000 profit. Then, of course, got the bug a bit more and decided to carry on in the market-and then lost that $30,000 in another share transaction. His effective balance after his dealings was nil. In other words, he made no money and he lost no money, so one would expect that at the end of the year when his tax bill came he would only need to pay tax according to his PAYE figure. But it does not work that way.

Under section 26aaa the Australian Taxation Office simply takes the $30,000 and adds it to his PAYE income, which makes a total of $55,000. The tax on that would be $19,801, using today's rates. We must add $687.50 for Medicare and $16,081 for provisional tax, giving a total of $36,569. If we deduct what he has already paid in PAYE tax, we are left with a net liability of $29,887.50.

Of course, not having any share profits as at 31 March next year-I would say that he would be scared right out of the market, thinking `I will stay on wages for the rest of my life; I am not going to do that any more'-he can then ask for a provisional readjustment and that provisional tax will be wiped off. In other words, his total tax bill, after having wiped out that $16,081, will be $13,806. That is the bill he will be getting, and he will be getting that bill even though he made no profit on his transactions. One way or another, like it or not, he will have to foot the bill. I know that he has capital losses to wipe off against his capital gains, but a fellow of modest means, on $25,000 year or whatever, with a family, having been scared off after his first time in business or share trading will probably not be game to try anything like that again. He will never, unless he gets a capital gain somewhere by selling one of grandma's paintings or something like that, get a chance to wipe that capital loss off, so he is left with this $13,806 tax bill to pay. Worse still, he might have borrowed $2,000 to buy those shares in the first place. I stress that he could be a very ordinary wage earner, such as a truck driver, an office worker or whatever you like. It could happen to anyone. As I said, he could even have borrowed the money. So, I put that scenario forward as a very simple example of the problems people face, and on about 31 March next year dozens and dozens of these cases will crop up right around Australia. I implore the Government to take this matter on board and see that something is done.

The last point I make on taxation matters, Madam Acting Deputy President, is one that I have already spoken about in this chamber before; that is, problems with provisional tax since we have gone onto the quarterly system. There are computer problems around the country in that when people pay their quarterly instalments and then get their final instalment out at the end of the year, they do not have their credits. That is simply put down to computer error. It is said that there are computer faults, or that they are not working. The trouble is that our taxpayers are suffering because of this. To give an example, I quote from a letter that I have received:

It appears that the Tax Office is not fully recognising past provisional tax payments in the assessment of quarterly provisional tax. Consequently, wrong assessments have been issued by the Tax Office and taxpayers are being forced to effectively pay double tax.
In a lot of cases, of course, people have to borrow money to pay this tax. The letter continues:
In a number of cases, the double tax payment runs into thousands of dollars. While the Tax Office recognises the problem-
and it does recognise it; it does not try to hide from it-

it is advising taxpayers to remit their payments or suffer the consequences of the very severe penalty payments. I find this situation extraordinary as taxpayers are being financially penalised by an error that has occurred exclusively within the Tax Office.

It is as simple as that. Of course, there is the added problem that when the Tax Office recognises that there has been a problem and finds the credit in there, there have been cases where taxpayers have been told, `Well, it is there; it can sit there as a credit for future tax assessed'. So, they have paid it twice, they are probably paying interest on the money they borrowed to pay the second round of assessment, and now it is sitting in the Tax Office and not getting interest. That is the problem I have heard of in Perth, in Adelaide, and in relation to the Brisbane computer. Whether there is one central computer, I do not know. I presume that if there is a problem everywhere it could be centralised.

These share trading/provisional tax concerns and the other provisional tax problems are serious matters affecting many taxpayers. The Government has to do some quick work between now and 31 March next year to bring these problems into line.

DEBATE.TITLE: LAYING CHICKEN LEVY BILL 1988LAYING CHICKEN LEVY COLLECTION BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 23 March, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —This laying chicken levy legislation was foreshadowed last year when we passed the Egg Industry Research (Hen Quota) Levy Bill 1987. The situation is that egg marketing arrangements are, of course, a matter for State governments to administer. Under current arrangements for research sponsored by the egg industry with the aid of matching Commonwealth grants, egg producers contribute towards research through a levy imposed on their operative hen quota issued under State or Territory law. The relevance in this case is the Federal contribution towards research. These Bills essentially provide a contingency plan in case the present arrangements based on State hen quotas are abandoned, which would stop the flow of funds for research in this industry. The Bills provide for a standby levy mechanism which could be introduced without delay to ensure continuity in the egg research program. The mechanism agreed on with industry is a levy on hens hatched for egg production. A similar levy on chickens hatched for meat production provides industry contributions to the chicken meat research scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: The egg industry in Australia is a $200m per annum industry and recently egg producers have begun to develop profitable export markets. Australia has an efficient and highly rated poultry industry by world standards. Research is essential to retain this position. In September last year the industry won a $15m contract to supply egg products to Japan, in competition against subsidised products from the European Economic Community and the United States of America. The maximum levy which can be introduced under the proposed legislation is 10c per hen and the operative rate is to be set by the Australian Agricultural Council. The coalition is strongly supportive of research which increases the competitiveness of rural industries and the efficiency of the poultry industry, and will support these Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing two Bills today-the Laying Chicken Levy Bill 1988 and the Laying Chicken Levy Collection Bill 1988. The first of those Bills seeks to provide a standby levy mechanism to enable egg research to continue should present egg research levy arrangements, which are based on State hen quotas, become unworkable due to the abandonment of the quota system in one or more States. The second of the Bills makes arrangements for the collection of the levy that may be imposed if needed under the Laying Chicken Levy Bill 1988. As these Bills seek to ensure the continuation of research funding for the chicken industry, which the Australian Democrats welcome, I do take this opportunity to make a couple of brief comments on the 1986-87 annual report of the Chicken Meat Research Council. On pages 6 and 7 of that report we find the heading `Refinement of Husbandry Approaches and Address Welfare Issues' and the sub-heading `Research Trends and Results'. When this report was placed before us some months ago I particularly noted that there was a project concerned with the study of the self-selection of feeds by chickens four weeks of age. It indicated a number of things, and among them that chickens living in groups were able to balance their diets more effectively than individually accommodated chickens. Another project involved a study of the nesting behaviour of hens in order to alleviate the floor egg problem. The report said:

SPEECH.PARA: Experiments have been conducted to encourage hens to go up to nest boxes, and attract them into nests, in order to identify the cause and possible remedies for the floor egg problem. It has been found that the main reasons for floor laying appear to be: the poor perching ability of some hens; the lack of prior experience of being in a nest; and the hens not realising that the nest boxes are potential nesting sites.

I do not think it would surprise anybody if I, of all people, were to be horrified by this. In case Senator Watson and Senator Walters are listening avidly in their rooms, and knowing as I do that they often wager a little something on the side as to how quickly in an egg Bill debate I mention free-range eggs, I now mention free-range eggs. But because of the question of the poor perching ability of hens and because it is noted in the same research project that chickens living in groups can better balance their diets than chickens living alone, I do raise the issue of animal husbandry in intensive farming. I think it is something we should all bear in mind. My first reaction was that if I were confined to a very small space I do not think I would be able to stay on my perch, either, so I am not surprised the chickens cannot stay on theirs a lot of the time.

Certainly many members of this chamber engage in fairly strenuous physical exercise because they know the value of that exercise to their own physical health and well-being. I think Senator Michael Baume, who normally sits here on my right-somewhat appropriately, I believe-is a regular tennis partner of Senator Cooney who, not so appropriately perhaps, sits on my left. I know that Senator Patterson, who is in the chamber, engages in strenuous swimming at every possible opportunity. It is one of her major interests. Senator Button, I read in the paper one day, was once jogging around Lake Burley Griffin when he should have been here doing something else. I have seen Senator Alston gulping in the pollution of Melbourne at lunchtimes in an attempt to stay fit. If one gets here early in the morning one sees Senator Crowley coming in from her morning's exercise. We want to engage in exercise, and I think that is the very least that we could enable our chickens to do. I certainly hope that the Chicken Meat Research Council will look very seriously at that.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the increased cost? What about the consumer?

—My colleague behind me refers to the cost of eggs. There is a bit of a furore about this in Victoria at the moment. While eggs remain under $2 a dozen, eggs being almost the perfect food and one egg on a piece of toast being a good meal, I think they are still pretty cheap.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to refer to a section in this report which refers to investigations being undertaken into the harmful effects of weed seed contaminants in cereal grains which are fed to poultry. I am very pleased that contaminants of whatever kind are being looked at by the research body. I did see in the Canberra Times quite recently, in February of this year, an article relating the fact that traces of insecticide had been found in New South Wales chickens. Certainly these traces were not above the maximum residue level but it has been found that the wood shavings used in the chicken's breeding areas have contained chemicals such as DDT, aldrin and heptachlor, which of course are chemicals with which we are having considerable contamination and residue problems. I do hope that the research authority will be looking not just at the effective contaminants in feed for chickens but also at contaminants in their general environment. As members of this place will know, chemicals in agricultural production generally is a matter of major concern. So I just make those few remarks and reiterate that the Australian Democrats will support the Bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Lewis and Senator Powell for their remarks in this debate. I have nothing to say in reply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —The Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Act 1986, the basis of the new dairy marketing arrangements, imposed a levy on butter and cheese produced after 1 July of that year. Butter and cheese exported was exempted from the levy, with the exception of small consignments and those containing less than 25 per cent of dairy produce, in the mistaken belief by the Australian Dairy Corporation that it would be easier to impose the domestic levy on small packages rather than exempt small packages from paying the levy. The intent was to reduce administration costs but the opposite has occurred and the Australian Dairy Corporation has requested the removal of these restrictions, recommending that retrospective to 1 July 1986 all exports be exempt from the levy. The limit also discriminated against a manufacturer who exported a large amount of butter or cheese in small consignments compared with one who exported small amounts in large consignments.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Dairy Corporation cites savings in administrative costs and hence savings to the dairy industry at large as the reason for this amendment. The purpose of this Bill is to make it clear and specific that all dairy product exported, irrespective of the weight of the export consignment or the percentage of dairy products, be exempt from the domestic levy on butter and cheese, and that that be back-dated to 1 July 1986 so as to reimburse those who have paid the levy. The coalition parties will be supporting the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis has clearly outlined the purpose of the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill. However, there is one very small sector of the dairy industry that does not believe this Bill goes far enough. On a recent trip through Gippsland I had the very great pleasure of visiting the Gippsland blue cheese factory. Many honourable senators will be familiar with this cheese, and any honourable senators who have travelled on Qantas in first class will know that this cheese is served as a speciality cheese.
—What cheese is it?

—Gippsland blue cheese, Senator. Five years ago this small factory did not exist. I would like to tell the Senate the story of the development of this cheese, because I think it is a story of enterprise, innovation and sheer determination. A farmer in Gippsland decided he would try to be innovative. I think he rues the day he did. He set out, in conjunction with a young man living in the area who had been trained in cheese manufacturing, to develop a small speciality cheese industry. They went into considerable debt because, as many honourable senators will be aware, such a project requires extensive capital. They also demonstrated some foresight by attaching to the factory an afternoon tea or small luncheon area where tourists could come to watch the cheese being made. As well as trying to get into the cheese business they were also opening up this area to the tourist industry. It is a beautiful area; in fact the locals call it God's own country.

SPEECH.PARA: So here we have a farmer attempting to move into an area and be innovative. What has happened? First of all, he has gone into enormous debt to do this, and he and his directors claim that, if State and Federal regulations continue in the way they are going, the Gippsland blue factory will be further in the red. We will be the poorer for it. Why? Because this cheese, unlike our other dairy products, comes under the import replacement category. There has been a significant demand for this cheese and for other cheeses in the speciality area produced by places such as Jindi, which is just down the road from the blue cheese factory. They are working towards import replacement and, in addition, working towards building up an export market. But they have been daunted by the regulations in the industry, both at a State and Federal level. Local people who may have gone into the industry have also been daunted. Their vision was to have blue vein cheese made in their factory; to have the Jindi factory, a small factory down the road which produces brie, co-operating with them; and also to encourage other farmers in the area to set up specialty cheese factories. Their vision was that they would be able to build up an export industry and be able to export quantities in refrigerated containers from that area, benefiting from the economies of scale and, in addition, from sharing laboratory facilities.

I have learnt a lot about specialty cheese manufacturing in the last little while, and every batch of cheese, especially if it is for export, has to be tested. That is fine if one is exporting large volumes of cheddar cheese, but it is not fine if one is trying to get into the export market and export small quantities of specialty cheese. The people involved believe it is impossible for them ever to become exporters as the testing of this cheese is so costly that once that cost is spread across their small batch it will make the price of the cheese prohibitive.

Another problem they have expressed to me concerns the current levy. I will put honourable senators in the picture. The cheese factory is on a dairy farm. The dairy farm is owned by one set of proprietors and the cheese factory by another, some of the proprietors being common to both. A quarter of the milk is sent to the local co-operative and is subjected to the dairy levy but they get back the stepped-up payments involved, as do all other producers who contribute milk to the co-operative. Three-quarters of their milk goes into their own little factory and, lo and behold, we find that they now have to pay the levy on the milk that goes to their own factory across the paddock and because they are not involved in the export market they do not get the step-up payment back on that three-quarters. So what has this meant? It has meant that one of the directors, who is the technical adviser, has had to go out and seek employment in a university to make up the loss resulting from contributing to this levy.

It seems to me that although the industry as a whole agrees with this legislation it is very typical of the head in the sand attitude that we have to innovation in Australia. New Zealand stole the march on us in the selling of wool products. They were first on the market in the United States with woollen underblankets; they were the first in the United States with woollen coats; and they are going to steal the march on us with specialty cheeses. Already they are ahead of us. I would like to draw attention to the need for the Federal Government to attend to the needs of minority groups in industries such as the dairy industry, especially those that are doing exactly what the Government wants to do-replace imports and develop exports. This is what these innovative people in the specialty cheese industry are trying to do, and they are being hindered in every way, both State and Federal. I guess the reason I am speaking today is to ask that the Government address this issue and ensure that legislation, even though it might already suit the majority, also include incentives and encouragement for the sort of project that we have seen with the Gippsland blue. I believe this project ought to continue. I believe it ought to be supported in a way that is consistent with the way that large cooperatives and large proprietary companies are supported. I would make the plea that this issue be considered so that we are not beaten to the post by the New Zealand specialty cheese industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis has explained what the Dairy Produce Levy (No. 1) Amendment Bill seeks to do, but I want to go a little further into the dairy industry because there are some clouds on the horizon that I want to point out to the Senate and to the public servants over on the advisers benches. The problems of the dairy industry now will fade into insignificance if the Government's decision to open the door to free trade with New Zealand is left the way the Government proposes. As a senator representing the people of Queensland, I am aware of the concerns being expressed by the dairy industry in relation to this action by the Federal Government. I firmly believe that this move represents the greatest threat to the future profitability of the dairy industry in Australia. Since moves towards closer economic relations, CER, with New Zealand were started, the dairy industry has been actively involved in a number of discussions with the New Zealand dairy industry in order to secure an equitable agreement for dairy trade between the two countries.

SPEECH.PARA: It was the industry's belief that the memorandum of understanding drawn up as a result of these discussions would be allowed to continue into the future. But what happened? The Australian Labor Party has now sold out the industry by indicating that the agreement will not operate for a timeless period but will be terminated in line with the introduction of free trade arrangements which may now be in place by as early as 1990, one or two years hence. This decision has the potential to destroy the Australian dairy industry and force many dairy farmers from their properties and onto the unemployment queues.

Australian farmers want this Labor Government to consider the concept of fair trade rather than free trade. This Government is blind if it does not realise that there are substantial differences between the working of the New Zealand and Australian dairy industries. In New Zealand the industry operates under a system of cooperative companies controlled by the New Zealand Dairy Board. This board is responsible for all aspects of dairy production-the storage, packaging, distribution and financing of dairy products. It is through this system that returns are able to be pooled and a common price for the products provided to companies regardless of where those products are sold. By contrast the Australian dairy industry is relatively open and competitive.

Australian farmers cannot allow this Government to give New Zealand a stand-up start in trade between the two countries. Even Labor senators opposite agree-I know Senator Cook is riveted by this debate, but I want him to listen because he may be able to take the needs of the dairy industry back to Cabinet with him, and if he listens he will learn something and understand the situation-that numerous advantages are provided by the New Zealand Government that allow New Zealand farmers unfair advantages in any dairy trade exchange. The ability of the New Zealand Dairy Board to use its monopoly position to pool returns to farmers is a substantial benefit that is not enjoyed by our own farmers, whether they be Queensland dairy farmers or Victorian dairy farmers. This pooling provides a considerable benefit to New Zealand farmers. The pooling of farmers' returns for New Zealand access into the European Community is alone worth an average of around $9,000 per farmer.

But the most significant advantage is that the New Zealand Government has given the Dairy Board a $NZ750m loan, repayable over 40 years at the token interest rate of one per cent. How in the world can Australian dairy farmers compete against interest-free loans for the dairy industry in New Zealand? If that is not bad enough, in 1986 the New Zealand Government replaced this loan with a commercial loan of $150m. In effect, it gave the New Zealand Dairy Board $600m as a gift. If it was left in the bank, it would return to the New Zealand farmers a profit rate of 10 per cent, even on bank interest alone. This advantage is clearly something that this Government would not provide to the Australian farmers. I have often said that this Government has never been concerned with Australian farmers. It has one rule for secondary industry and another for primary industry, which is certainly the last cab off the rank.

The New Zealand Dairy Board has already moved to use this money to benefit its farmers. A New Zealand distribution company, Riviana (Australia) Pty Ltd, has already been purchased in Australia and the New Zealand industry is looking to expand this facility further, courtesy of the funding provided by its Government. The New Zealand strategy is clearly to develop and expand its distribution in Australia to capitalise on the loan that it has in order to sell higher quantities of dairy products in this country. I am not opposed to free trade but I am opposed to another country getting government subsidies to take the market of our Australian farmers off us. I do not mind people playing on a flat field-that is referred to around this place often enough-but the field gets awfully rugged because it is lop-sided and tilted against the Australian farmer who has to compete against heavily subsidised products coming into Australia. That is the view of the dairy industry of Australia, and I back that view sincerely. I know all members on this side of the House would agree with me. I look over at Senator Devlin from Tasmania, and he is nodding in agreement too. I know he is concerned about the dairy farmers of Tasmania.

If this Government is intent on opening the doors to free trade, it should be aware of the catastrophic effects this will have on all industries affected by a corrupted world marketplace for their product. I can see this affecting all our rural produce. Australian farmers are the most efficient farmers in the world. They have no peer. But they cannot compete against subsidised products. Labor should be very wary of destroying the Australian dairy industry in the interests of free trade. I believe we should be looking at fair trade based around the current memorandum of understanding as negotiated by the dairy industries of both New Zealand and Australia.

New Zealand and Australia are by far the lowest cost producers of dairy products in the world. If the Federal Government does not take into consideration the benefits provided to the New Zealand industry by its Government, we may have a situation where our efficient industry, an industry recognised worldwide as being competitive and effective, is destroyed by another highly competitive industry which is subsidised and aided as a result of interference by the New Zealand Government. If we do not heed those warnings of the dairy industry, farmers could well be wiped out by the short-sighted approach of this Labor Government I would urge this Government to reconsider urgently opening Pandora's box, and let the industry negotiate its own memorandum of understanding. If it does not heed these warnings there will be a drastically reduced industry by the turn of this century, in around 10 years time.

I believe this Government is not concerned about the welfare of farmers. It certainly has not displayed any concern in the time it has been in office, over the last five years. The question has to be asked: is this Government more concerned about free trade or bringing down the price index at the expense of our farmers? I suggest very strongly that that question must concern every member of this Senate. If Labor does not take action to stand behind the memorandum of understanding, it will be doing little more than importing artificially cheap produce and exporting jobs and ruining the family farm that is the backbone of this nation.

Another area of concern in the dairy industry is the fight which appears to be coming ever closer because of the strong rumour that there will be a considerable increase in the sales tax on flavoured milk in the May mini-Budget. In the last Budget the Government placed a 10 per cent sales tax on flavoured milk, under great pressure from manufacturers of carbonated products. The sales tax on flavoured milk should not be there in the first place.

—Has the attention of the Minister for Finance been drawn to a report on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Country Hour yesterday that the Queensland Graingrowers Association has demanded grants from the Commonwealth rather than loans under the natural disaster relief arrangements for drought affected Queensland farmers who are not able to service their debts? Is it true that the State and not the Commonwealth has constitutional responsibility for drought relief? What is the Government's response to the demand for Commonwealth grants by the Queensland Graingrowers Association?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to the last part of the question, about the Commonwealth's response to a demand for grants, the answer is an unequivocal no. Regarding the second part of the question, it is true that it is the constitutional responsibility of the State Government and not the Commonwealth Government to provide relief of this type, if any is to be provided, which is spelt out very clearly in Budget Paper No. 4 on pages 98 and 99. I will not bother to quote it, but if anybody wants to look up the exact words they are easily obtainable. Anybody who supports the proposition that grants should be made available in lieu of loans for natural disaster relief or for anything else is advocating an increase in taxation. Let us be perfectly clear about that. Anybody who advocates that change is advocating an increase in taxation. I do not know whether that applies to Senator Stone as a representative of the Queensland National Party, the State branch of which has been campaigning for virtually free money from the Commonwealth for it to hand out at its discretion for a considerable time.

ANSWER.PARA: Apart from the fact that demands for grants are demands to increase taxation, any business which is in the position of not being viable with concessional finance at 4.5 per cent, which is the rate normally charged, but has to have a grant, is by definition an insolvent business. The Commonwealth Government is not in the business of guaranteeing business solvency, and nor should it be. Indeed, if any government were to put itself into the position where it guaranteed the solvency of every business in the country, the system would break down. I am sure that Senator Stone understands the reasons why the system would break down if any government were silly enough to offer grants under those circumstances.

There would be a particular objection to offering grants to the Queensland Government for this purpose, because we could not be sure where the grant money might finish up. It might finish up in the Bjelke-Petersen Foundation or some other Queensland National Party slush fund. Indeed, as I have informed the Senate before, in the past some of the loan funds have finished up in peculiar hands, if I may say so, in breach of the guidelines which the Commonwealth Government lays down. Some time ago a Mr Michael Behan-no relation to Senator Beahan-who was indeed an apparatchik of the Queensland National Party, was granted a $145,000 loan in breach of the Commonwealth guidelines. It is difficult enough to deal with Queensland when we are giving loans. It would be much more dangerous to deal with Queensland if what is presently provided as a loan, and therefore must ultimately be repaid, were to be provided as a grant.

The existing arrangements for natural disaster relief are tied to a formula, and have been, from memory, since 1984. The result of that formula, when applied to Queensland, is that the State Government must provide the first $14m of relief from its own resources-I am using round figures-the next $10m is matched by the Commonwealth on a dollar for dollar basis and beyond that figure, which in the case of Queensland is $24m, the Commonwealth provides $3 for every $1 from the State.

I am also informed, via an article by Mr Peter Clack in the Brisbane Courier-Mail, that Queensland's Primary Industries Minister, Mr Neville Harper, said that up to $25m was outstanding in bad debts. So what his predecessor describes as a piddling amount of $145,000 which went quite improperly-indeed, I suggest, corruptly-to Mr Michael Behan, the Queensland National Party apparatchik, has apparently grown to $25m. I believe that I said some time ago that, when Queensland got a new Premier, I would be writing to him to see what could be done about tightening up the at best slack administration of the scheme by the Queensland State authorities in the past.

Finally, it should be noted for the record that, if any government were to follow the policy direction advocated by Senator McGauran at the Senate Estimates committee hearings last week when he proposed that Australia would be better off if we did not have any taxes, there would be no money available to provide loans for natural disaster relief, let alone to provide grants for natural disaster relief. But then we have become accustomed to hearing, from one prong of the National Party's forked tongue, demands for additional handouts to everybody in sight or to everybody who the National Party thinks can be bribed into voting for it and, with the other prong of the forked tongue, simultaneous demands for reductions in taxation.

Secondly, does this not mean that Senator Evans's statement, and the Minister's statement of yesterday, that Australian uranium has not been diverted for military uses, were false? Thirdly, is it not a fact that the United States Oak Ridge enrichment plant, where Australian uranium is also enriched, is also a joint military-civilian enrichment plant? Fourthly, is it not a fact that the Australian uranium sold to Finland is enriched in the Soviet Union, where civil and military functions are combined? Fifthly, is it not a fact that there are at least 15 other nuclear facilities in France, including three reprocessing plants, which produce plutonium and which perform both military and civilian functions? Finally, if the Minister is denying that Australian uranium in enrichment streams ends in weapons, can he therefore give a categorical assurance that all joint military-civil plants are stopped and cleaned out between military and civil batches?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the article--
—Again.

—No, I have not seen the article. I am not an avid reader, it might surprise everyone, of the Cogemagazine. As far as I know it does not come through my office every day. I do not read it. It appears from the question Senator Sanders poses that it is a magazine of a French company that makes bombs.
—This is the only broth spoilt by one cook.
—I did not hear what Senator Chaney said, but I am sure it was not of any use to this debate, and I am sure it does not help to throw any light on the question that has been put.
—Nothing you have said so far has helped either. What about getting on with it?

—That is not entirely true. I remember being in the Senate yesterday when the Opposition's spokesman said that we had put down a very good statement indeed. Perhaps the honourable senator should talk to Senator Austin Lewis about the statement before he asserts that nothing we have said throws any light on the subject.

ANSWER.PARA: To return to Senator Sanders's question, I have not read the magazine. I notice that he did not quote explicitly from the magazine, but described what the magazine said. He would appreciate that, on a matter such as this, where it is necessary to be very precise and very pedantic about what is or is not the case, I will check the magazine and so forth before I accept that. But it does appear, from what Senator Sanders said, that it is a technical explanation of what occurs. I am pleased to observe also from the question that at last there is a recognition that there are two French factories, the Tricastin factory and the Pierrelatte factory, and that the Tricastin one enriches for the civil program and the Pierrelatte factory enriches for the weapons program. Up to 20 per cent is enriched for the civil program, and up to 90 per cent for the weapons program. The important point to make in answering Senator Sanders's question is that Australian uranium goes to the Tricastin plant and not the Pierrelatte plant, and to the 20 per cent enrichment program.

TALK.START.PARA: —But they have closed down the first stage at Pierrelatte.

—It is entirely irrelevant, in terms of Australian uranium, whether the first or all of the stages at Pierrelatte have been closed down, because Pierrelatte is dedicated to the making of bombs. Australian origin nuclear material is put into the civil cycle in France, which is, as Senator Sanders properly identified, the Tricastin plant.

ANSWER.PARA: I now turn to the six questions put to me by Senator Sanders. With respect to the first question, I would have thought that this was understood, but I will repeat it. Australian origin material enters the Tricastin civil program plant for enrichment and an equal amount based on the principle of equivalence, the core principle in terms of safeguards-which was explained in the document that I read to the Senate yesterday reporting on the outcome of our investigations into the allegation in the Der Spiegel magazine-leaves the Tricastin plant for fuel fabrication, so there is no contribution of Australian nuclear material to the French weapons inventory.

Senator Sanders then asked whether this meant that Senator Evans's statements in the past have been false. The answer to that question is one word-no. Senator Sanders's next question related to the Oak Ridge enrichment plant in the United States of America. I am advised that the Oak Ridge enrichment plant contains two separate streams-one for civil use and one for military use. In fact, I am advised that the streams are not under the one roof, as it were, or beside each other so that they are easy to divert; I am advised that a roadway physically separates both streams and that the Australian origin nuclear material is in the civil stream.

Senator Sanders's fourth question was about the Soviet Union and Finland. Of course, Finland is a customer for Australian uranium and as such full Australian safeguards apply. The Australian origin nuclear material which was enriched in the USSR-but that has not been the case now for some years-for Finland was on the basis of all in, all out. That is to say, Australian origin nuclear material entering the Soviet Union is processed, and all Australian origin nuclear material in the form of either uranium or the tailings comes out again and the equivalence principle obtains.

In answer to Senator Sanders's fifth question, I point out that Australia's concern is with plants which process Australian origin nuclear material, and all such material is accounted for. In answer to Senator Sanders's sixth question, I indicate that all Australian origin nuclear material is accounted for in the civil program and has not been diverted to military programs, and therefore the question of the cleaning of plants is not relevant.

In conclusion, a couple of other points need to be made because over the past few days we have been favoured with the presence in Australia of Dr Hans Blix, the Director-General of the International Atomic Energy Agency (IAEA), which is set up under the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons. The Agency's sole purpose under the Treaty is to be the world's watchdog to prevent the diversion of uranium for civil use into military use.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has other functions now, as well. That is not its sole purpose.

—That is not its sole purpose, but its key and primary purpose is to guarantee that there is no diversion from civil to military use, and that is the point that is relevant to the questions that I have been asked. What does Dr Blix say? He says that under the charter of his authority over the past 25 years, the whole period for which the IAEA has operated, there has been no diversion from the civil cycle to the weapons cycle, and that that covers all uranium from whatever source and not just Australian origin nuclear material. Another thing that Dr Blix said, and this has not been quoted or recognised in this whole debate, is that Australian uranium-and he has said this to me personally-has not added to the supply of uranium for military purposes. So with all those considerations I conclude by saying that everything we have said in a comprehensive reply to the allegations in Der Spiegel which relate to Senator Sanders's question is confirmed and there is nothing more to add.

—I have a supplementary question. I apologise for taking up any more time but, if possible, I would like the Minister for Resources to clarify his statement about the Soviet Union, all in, all out, and equivalence. All in, all out indicates a batch process and we understand equivalence to be chasing the paper and not the uranium. I ask the Minister to clarify his statement.

—I do not accept that the equivalence principle is simply chasing paper and not the uranium. The paper is a way of identifying where the uranium is, and it is matchable to physical quantities. The all in, all out principle is not at all inconsistent with the equivalence principle because in putting the yellowcake through the process to bring it up to the standard of fuel rods other things develop, and they come out as well as the equivalent quantity.
