The statement that is now being prepared will be ready in draft form by, I think, next March and it will then be published and available for public comment for some seven months, I think, until October. There will then be a period for the Government to consider those reports and I imagine that a decision will be made in about March 1990. So there is quite some time before the Government sits down--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who's doing it?

—I do not have the name of the company; I will find out for the honourable senator. That will be a fairly lengthy process but I think all senators would agree that, given the importance of the issues involved, it is worth while having a full investigation. Obviously the environmental and cultural values of the region will be taken into account. I am aware of reports that 3,000 fish were recently killed in the bay. I think the reports said that this occurred as a result of naval explosives testing. I am not yet certain why the Navy had to conduct testing in the bay. I have asked for details of that and as soon as they have been provided I shall naturally make them available.

ANSWER.PARA: In regard to any other development that may take place in the region, registration of Jervis Bay obviously places constraints on the Commonwealth. Commonwealth Ministers are bound to consider areas of the National Estate when they are looking at Government decisions. However, they do not place constraints on either State or local governments. That being the case, we will have a problem with some developments if State and local governments tend to ignore that listing. All I can do as Minister responsible is urge the New South Wales Government and councils in the region to take note of the listing and, hopefully, to make sure that developments do not occur until we have the results of the environmental impact statement, until we have had a period of public comment, and until we can all examine the results of that process.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister agree that, notwithstanding the improvement in our balance of payments position in the current financial year because of the largely unforeseen rise in the prices of our major exports, Australia is today still running the largest current account deficit of all the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) countries except Norway? Does the Minister also agree that the heavy dependence of our balance of payments on future commodity prices, when combined with our huge debt servicing obligations, means that the structural nature of our deficit is worse than that of most other OECD countries? Against that background, does the Minister agree with the Treasurer's recent prediction that the worst is over for Australian living standards, and that Australia is no longer heading down that Argentinean road to which the Minister himself referred in his very sound remarks to the meeting of Lawyers for Labor in Perth on 20 September last?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not sure whether I got all those questions down, but I think I got enough to cover them, anyway. The honourable senator referred to the `unforeseen' increase in export prices over the past 15 months or so. I am not sure whether it was unforeseen; it is certainly true that the terms of trade improved for the year ended December 1987 by some 7.6 per cent over what they had been in December 1986. Most of that improvement was, of course, due to the rise in export prices, which naturally is very welcome. However, it remains true that our terms of trade and, implicitly, our export prices are still very substantially below what they were 2 1/2 years ago or thereabouts. I think they are still some 10 per cent or so below what they were at that point.

ANSWER.PARA: On the question of Australia's current account deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product (GDP) being the second highest of all the OECD countries, I do not know about that, although I think I read in this morning's Australian Financial Review that that was the case. I was asked whether the combination of a current account deficit of the size that Australia is running and foreign debt is one that makes the country vulnerable to external shocks. The answer to that has to be yes. There is no secret about that. I have been saying that, and a number of other people in the Government who are involved with Budget preparation and economic policy have been saying the same thing.

Finally, Senator Stone referred me to some recent comments made by the Treasurer. If I remember correctly, I was asked almost the same question last week. I do not know whether I can remember to give exactly the same answer-or, as my very witty colleague Senator Evans said the other day when quoting himself, he hoped that he could do it with more confidence than President Reagan. I will not attempt to quote myself, as I do not have the record of what I said here, but it went something like this: The rate of change over the past two years, as shown by the most important indicator, that is, the current account deficit as a proportion of gross domestic product, has fallen from 6 per cent to about 4 per cent-although nobody can be sure of this year's outcome-and probably a little lower than that, notwithstanding that yesterday's figures for the month of March were less favourable than most people had expected.

That is a very rapid rate of change; to bring down the current account deficit by a full 2 percentage points of GDP in two years is very significant. Just what level could be regarded as being safe is a matter of some judgment, but I think there would be little disagreement that, if it was brought down another 2 percentage points, that is, to 2 per cent of GDP, we could feel reasonably secure. I believe that the Treasurer's remarks were made in that context and that that is the context in which they should be received.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question: In light of the closing comments of the Minister in his response, do I take it that the Minister is saying that, having achieved, with the help of a major increase in export prices this year, a reduction in the current account deficit from 6 per cent to 4 per cent of GDP, that is, 2 percentage points, we have at least-and I would underline the words `at least'-a further 2 percentage points reduction to achieve in the future? Against that background, I repeat my earlier question: In those circumstances, does the Minister agree with the Treasurer's recent remarks that the worst is over and that we are no longer heading down the Argentinean road?

—I do not think the Treasurer said those last few words. The point is that, if we can maintain the very rapid rate of progress that has been made over the past couple of years, I think we can see light at the end of the tunnel.
—If we can maintain it, how can the worst be over?

—Nobody can be certain. Senator Stone is one of the few people who never had any doubt about the infallibility of their economic prophecies: the catch is that he was nearly always wrong, as Michael Stutchbury pointed out, with a lot of specific evidence, in an article in the Financial Review some 15 days ago. There was in the question implicit criticism that the rate of adjustment had not been fast enough. It is probably true that under particular economic policies a faster rate of adjustment could have been achieved, but almost inevitably that would have entailed driving the economy into a catastrophic recession in order to close the current account deficit, by suppressing total demand to the point where imports shrank to the extent that the current account deficit was wiped out. It might have been technically feasible to do that but it would be highly speculative as to the unemployment rate that would be associated with it. Most people would not put it at below 20 per cent-a sort of early 1930s-type scenario. It may be that it could have been done that way, but I do not believe that there are many people, either supporters of this Government or supporters of the other side of politics, who would have wanted us to overcome the current account problem in that way, particularly when there are other ways of doing so, although not as quickly.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I ask the Minister whether he has seen the letter from the Tasmanian Premier, Robin Gray, in Tuesday's Australian Financial Review, in which Mr Gray states:

QUESTION.PARA: The level of Commonwealth assistance (including all general and specific purpose payments, both recurrent and capital) to the States and the Northern Territory . . . has fallen in real terms since 1984-85 by 9.6 per cent.
Is that assertion by Mr Gray true?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I did indeed read that letter last Tuesday and my reaction was that either it was a complete fabrication or it had been fiddled. The answer was that it was not a complete fabrication but the figures had certainly been fiddled. We are quite accustomed, of course, to Mr Gray doing this sort of thing, especially on the eve of a Premiers Conference, when he feels the need to do a bit of chest thumping, as do most State Premiers. Mr Gray has a particular need to do so because he has to explain away his mismanagement of Tasmanian State finances over a number of years.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact is that 1984-85, which was the year Mr Gray selected as his base year, was the end of a triennium in which payments to the States increased in real terms by 10.7 per cent, with `real terms' defined as the nominal amounts adjusted for the State and local government recurrent expenditure deflator, which covers the great majority of State government spending. Just after that year Australia's export prices collapsed and there was a need for major economic adjustments. For the years from 1984-85 to 1987-88 payments to the States in real terms have declined not by the 9.6 per cent that Mr Gray asserts but by 2 1/2 per cent, again measured by the State and local government recurrent expenditure deflator.

The figure of 2.5 per cent real defined over, I remind the Senate, a three-year period, I believe was no more than the States could reasonably have been expected to bear as an adjustment due to the export price collapse and the consequent economic problems that created. Measured against the consumer price index the decline over that period is higher but, as I have already explained, it is not appropriate to use the consumer price index in this context. The proper index to be used is the one which most accurately reflects the actual expenditure patterns of State governments and that is the State and local government recurrent expenditure deflator. The reason that that deflator increased by much less than the consumer price index is, of course, the success of the Federal Government's wages policy, the success of the accord and the restraint which has been shown by public sector employees and most private sector employees as well. So, in summary, what Mr Gray has done is a double fiddle. He chose as the base year the pinnacle of expenditure, then implicitly asserted it was a plateau and then he adjusted that pinnacle by the use of a shonky index.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. It relates to the Minister's extraordinary explanation yesterday in response to Senator Durack's question on the reasons for the delay in the completion of the Australian Federal Police investigations into non-disclosure by the Australian Labor Party of the Harris-Daishowa election campaign donation last year. The Minister will recall that in his reply yesterday he said that the Australian Federal Police inquiries `have been prolonged due to difficulties in arranging mutually convenient times to interview two witnesses'. I ask the Minister, firstly, what precisely are the difficulties in arranging mutually convenient times? Secondly, who are the two witnesses? Thirdly, are they members of the Australian Labor Party? Fourthly, since when has justice in Australia been conducted on the basis of mutual convenience?

—In answering the question yesterday I was relaying to the Senate the information which had been provided to me by the Australian Federal Police. It is quite clear that, where they need to discuss matters with those whom they think might have useful information in relation to an investigation or inquiry that they are undertaking, the timing of the discussions with those persons cannot be a matter of compulsion, though obviously the more expeditiously they can be carried out the better. I have no information whatsoever on the question of who might be involved, have never sought it and have never been provided with it. I would not expect to be provided with that sort of operational detail. I am sure the matter is being progressed by the Australian Federal Police investigators as expeditiously as is possible but within those constraints.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I understand the reasons for sensitivity in the Minister's inability to answer some of those questions but is he telling the Senate that he does not know what the difficulties are in arranging mutually convenient times? Why should not the interviewing of witnesses in such an important matter be compulsory? Why should it wait on mutual convenience?

—To answer the first supplementary question, no, I do not know precisely what the difficulties are: I have never been informed by the Australian Federal Police what they are, but they say there have been difficulties in arranging mutually convenient times in relation to persons, once again whose identity I do not know. I have never been informed of their identity, nor have I sought to know.
—How long will this delay go on before you ask?

—I do not intend to ask. I have no intention of asking. As far as compulsion is concerned, I would hope the police, when conducting normal inquiries, are never in a position to compel people to make certain arrangements of the sort that the honourable senator is implying should be made. There has to be mutuality in relation to calling on people to provide information of this character. In relation to the National Crime Authority, there are certain powers to compel persons to attend and give answers but that is a very extraordinary power which was bestowed on that body by special Act of Parliament.

—My question is directed to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Being aware of the Minister's concern for those people who have been disadvantaged by the World Heritage listing of the north Queensland rainforests, I draw the Minister's attention to criticism of the $75m compensation package announced on Friday, 15 April, for the effects of World Heritage listing of north Queensland rainforests. Can the Minister advise the Senate of the basis upon which the compensation package was arrived at?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: ARTS, SPORT, THE ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the criticism of the $75m package. It has filtered through from a number of points. I have seen some Press releases from various people in the Queensland Government. It should be remembered first off that last year we had a two-month public consultation process in which we sought the views of people in north Queensland. Further to that, in order to make a proper decision, as honourable senators will be aware from the number of times I answered questions on it, the Government carried out extensive consultations with local government in the area, the timber mill companies, the tourist operators, community organisations, conservation groups and indeed the timber workers.

ANSWER.PARA: In addition, the Commonwealth commissioned six independent studies on the social and economic impacts of World Heritage listing. Those studies looked into the regional economy, alternative employment creation, social impacts, the timber industry, the mining industry and the tourism industry. They were commissioned in October of last year and were completed and the reports given to the Government at various times in the early months of this year. They have been of great use to the Government and they were, of course, necessary in considering just what sort of compensation package the Government could come up with. They have provided important information for the development of a discussion paper on future management arrangements for the area. It has now been finalised and I would hope to release it tomorrow for a period of public consultation until 22 July.

Of course, I have always said that the reports of the studies to which I have referred, the consultancies, would be released once the Government had considered them. The period of Government consideration has ended. In keeping with that promise, I have already arranged for copies of them to be sent to the offices of Senators Boswell, Puplick and, I think, Sanders. I am endeavouring to have them sent to Senator Durack. I am not sure whether they have yet reached his office. I cannot say that I have a plentiful supply of copies at this point, but they will be made available to interested senators if they care to contact my office. Similarly, that will be the case with the Press. Hopefully, over the next week, as more copies are made available, there will be less of a problem with access to those studies. It is those studies and the consultations to which I referred which formed the basis of the information that we used in the package. It is because we did all of that that the package has been received as well as it has.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women to her answer to Senator Zakharov on 17 March this year with respect to Australia's report to the United Nations Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination Against Women and to that part of her response to that question in which, on four separate occasions, she specifically called for a bipartisan approach to status of women issues, in fact, using that term. In light of those calls for bipartisanship, how does she explain the fact that, of the 372 people invited to the launch of the Rural Women's Survey, some 41 were Labor politicians, both male and female and, according to the list, no Liberal, National or Democrat politicians were invited? What is her explanation for calling for bipartisanship in this place and deliberately making outside functions strictly party political and partisan, other than sheer hypocrisy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to answer Senator Vanstone's question. I am pleased that she agrees with me about bipartisan support for the National Agenda for Women. I remind the Senate that it is the Government's view that there should be bipartisan support for the National Agenda. I am pleased that it is also Senator Vanstone's view. I quote from her address to the Liberal Party women's conference on 11 April:

ANSWER.PARA: At this point let me steal a phrase from my leader, John Howard. He used it on election night last year to describe the relationship between the two parties and the problems we face as a nation. It is equally true in the sense that I now use it, and that is to describe the relationship between Liberal and Labor women and issues affecting the status of women. What unites us is far greater than what divides us.
I welcome that statement by Senator Vanstone. She went on to say--

TALK.START.PARA: —Now we know you can read, answer the question.
—I am coming to that. Senator Vanstone went on to say:

ANSWER.PARA: We agree that the Commonwealth Government's economic policies are the means by which the Government must best ensure a bright and secure future for all present and future members of our nation. We want women to make better use of the opportunities available to them and for more opportunities to be made available. There are so many areas where there are improvements to be made and we share with Labor a commitment to find the right solutions.
There is no doubt about it: Senator Vanstone and I are on the same wavelength in terms of the National Agenda for Women.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question was not about the National Agenda.
—It was about the launch of the Rural Women's Survey. I understand that Senator Vanstone sent a staff person to the launch of the Rural Women's Survey?
—No, wrong again.
—I ask whether Senator Vanstone sent a staff person to the launch of the National Agenda.
—No, I did not.

—I wonder why not. I will give a specific answer to Senator Vanstone's question, but she should be aware that she is making gross allegations about the participation of those rural women if she is suggesting that they are all Labor voters. I am sure that Senator Boswell and Senator Stone would be very concerned about the allegations Senator Vanstone is making, in suggesting that there has been some political manipulation of the mailing list. The point is that the mailing list was set down to attract the kind of women in Bathurst who would have been the most ready and able to participate.

—I take a point of order, Mr President. I understand that you do not have the power to direct Ministers as to the content of their answer other than to direct them to be relevant. The Minister was asked about the Rural Women's Survey and whether this Government practises what it preaches. We have heard everything but that from the Minister in her answer. I ask you to direct her to answer the question.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Mr President, I can understand Senator Vanstone's embarrassment. I can understand her not being happy to have the contents of her speech revealed in this place, but I welcome her approach of bipartisan support. I have already undertaken in my answer to find out precisely who was on the mailing list. I do not think I can undertake to find out their political persuasion, as Senator Vanstone has suggested, but I certainly undertake to seek information regarding the substance of her question. I assure Senator Vanstone that she would have been invited to the function, as she was invited to the launch of the National Agenda.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Am I to take it from the Minister's answer that she denies that an extensive range of Labor parliamentarians were invited to the launch of the Rural Women's Survey and denies the allegation that I have made that no Liberal, National or Australian Democrat politicians were invited?
—I have already undertaken to get a specific answer about the alleged mailing list that Senator Vanstone is so concerned about, and I will do so.
—Mr President, I ask Senator Reynolds to table the excellent speech by Senator Vanstone from which she quoted.
—Mr President, I also ask, under the appropriate standing order, that Senator Vanstone table the document she just quoted from.
—On a point of order, Mr President: I do not think any standing order permits that request to be made. Although I do not think Senator Vanstone cares, I do not think she can be so directed.

—Senator Crowley, you cannot ask for the statement to be tabled. You can move it. I point out to all honourable senators and all Ministers that the Standing Orders Committee, in a report in November 1985, said that it was not necessary for Ministers to table speech notes-only documents.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance and Minister representing the Treasurer. Given the proliferation in the distribution and use of credit cards in Australia, I ask: Is the Minister concerned about the high level of interest rates charged on these cards? Secondly, in view of the fact that these accounts all carry compounding interest above 20 per cent and have not followed the downward trend of other commercial interest rates, will the Minister put pressure on the banking industry to reduce those interest rates, particularly as they are having a significant impact on low income earners with high consumer debt?
—I would have thought prima facie that low income earners with high debts would have difficulty in getting a credit card.
—They do, and that is the trouble. Maybe you should do something about it.

—I will get the fairy at the bottom of the garden to fix it up-how's that? I will refer that question to the Treasurer, but I am not sure what is being suggested. It is implied, it seems to me, that there should be some sort of government intervention or regulation other than credential-type regulation. I will see what the Treasurer's response is to that specific suggestion, but it would be somewhat inconsistent with the general thrust of Government policy over the last couple of years in regard to the financial system.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: TELEPHONE SERVICES: RURAL AND REMOTE AREAS

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 18 April Senator Bishop asked me a number of questions about a Telecom Australia advertisement about what was described as the world's loneliest phone box which appeared in the House Magazine in December last year concerning the installation of a public telephone at William Creek in South Australia at a stated cost of $1.6m. I undertook to obtain further information about this latest triumph for Telecom's public relations and to provide the honourable senator with a response, which is in the following terms.

ANSWER.PARA: The reference to $1.6m in the advertisement was in fact incorrect. I am advised by Telecom that the public telephone in question was only one aspect of a much larger $1.6m program undertaken by it as part of the rural and remote area program. That $1.6m bought a digital radio concentrator system which provides telecommunications services to persons living within an area of 26,000 square kilometres, some 45 separate customers and homesteads in all. Whatever may have been the case for the cost of the provision of the particular phone service referred to in the advertisement, this total service certainly could not have been provided for less than $100,000 by Aussat, which was Senator Bishop's suggestion, since the individual satellite earth stations of the type required each cost about $80,000.

Aussat was not in fact asked for a quotation, but Telecom, which is a 25 per cent shareholder in Aussat, estimates that the cost of providing each of these customers over the area in question with earth station facilities to access Aussat could be about $4m. As to ensuring that Telecom uses the cheapest means to service its customers, Telecom informs me that its studies showed that the use of terrestrial technologies, particularly digital radio concentrator systems, is the most cost effective way of providing basic rural and remote telecommunications services.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In Question Time Senator Chaney asked me a question concerning the War Crimes Amendment Bill and its applicability to Australian ex-servicemen and ex-servicewomen. He provided what he described as a compendious quote from the second reading speech of the Attorney-General on the Bill in another place.
—I did not use the word `compendious'.
—I thought the honourable senator said that it was concertinaed or put together from two different sources.
—Yes, but I did not use that expression.
—I beg the honourable senator's pardon. The quotation given by Senator Chaney at the time was:

ANSWER.PARA: No distinction is drawn . . . between members of the allied or axis forces, or between persons of different races or origin. Consistent with the Government's evenhanded policy, the Bill applies to any person who commits a war crime as defined.

That is the case. There is no exclusion clause or any quarantining of Australian ex-servicemen or ex-servicewomen in this regard. It is important to try to think through the types of activities in which Australian ex-servicemen might be alleged to have been involved during the Second World War, which is the war under consideration. It may be useful if one considered the most frequently quoted possible instance, which is the question whether Australian servicemen who took part in the Allied area bombardment of Germany would be liable to prosecution under the Bill. I am advised that the answer is that they would not be. Australians who took part in Allied bombing raids in Germany would not be covered by the Bill, because their actions were not wanton and were justified by military necessity within the terms of article 6 (b) of the Nuremberg Charter. That is the advice available to me on that particular example, and I think that it is the one most commonly thought of.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 14 April Senator Harradine asked me a question without notice about the requirement by overseas and Australian airlines for disabled passengers to complete forms relating to their fitness for air travel. I seek leave to incorporate the answer in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer read as follows-

The requirement is a general airline industry practice, adopted world-wide, governing clearance for travel by incapacitated travellers to enable airlines to determine what special services, if any, are required both inflight and at airports.

While the air travel medical clearance forms for Qantas, Ansett and Australian airlines do ask whether the passenger's incapacity will inconvenience other passengers, the forms are designed to provide for the welfare and comfort of all passengers with medical or physical limitations by seeking information from both the intending passenger and his/her physician on the type of travel and medical needs required. Airlines can then ensure that medically or physically disabled passengers are properly and appropriately seated and receive proper care and attention both inflight and at airports. This practice helps to ensure the safety and comfort of both disabled and other passengers.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON ENVIRONMENT, RECREATION AND THE ARTS

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the Leader of the Government in the Senate advising me of Senator Morris's resignation from the Standing Committee on the Environment, Recreation and the Arts and nominating Senator Collins to be a member of that Committee.

INTERJECT.PARA: That Senator Morris be discharged from further attendance on the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts and that Senator Collins be appointed a member of the Committee.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Crimes (Torture) Bill will enable Australia to ratify the Convention against Torture and Other Cruel, Inhuman or Degrading Treatment or Punishment which was signed by Australia on 10 December 1985. The Convention, generally known as `the Torture Convention', came into force on 26 June 1987, 30 days after the twentieth country, Denmark, deposited its instrument of ratification.

The Attorney-General announced the Government's decision to ratify the Convention at the Human Rights Congress in Sydney on 25 September 1987. Ratification of the Convention by Australia has been the subject of consultation with the States in the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General and there is general agreement with this decision.

Torture is an abhorrent practice and much work has been done in the councils of the United Nations to find practical ways of combating it. Australia has played a prominent part in such work and this Bill should be seen as a part of that process. In accordance with the provisions of the Convention, its main purpose is to deny safe haven in Australia to any person who, while acting officially, or at the instigation or behest of a person so acting, is involved in the torture of a person in another country. There are currently 28 parties to the Convention each of which has undertaken similar obligations to those embodied in this Bill.
As a party to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, Australia is already bound by the obligation in Article 7 of that Covenant which provides:

No one shall be subjected to torture or to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment. In particular, no one shall be subjected without his free consent to medical or scientific experimentation.

The Government takes the view that the laws of the States and Territories are already adequate to fulfil this obligation and the obligations of the Torture Convention insofar as acts committed within Australia are concerned. The Bill does not, therefore, apply to acts within Australia.

Instead, the substantive provisions in clause 6 of the Bill apply to any act of torture as defined in the Convention which is committed anywhere in the world outside Australia. The Bill does not apply retrospectively to acts of torture committed before the legislation comes into force. Australian domestic law will be applied to an Australian citizen and to any person present in Australia who has committed an act of torture as defined in the Convention. The law to be applied will, in substance, be the law of the State or Territory where the offender is prosecuted.

In the Government's view, adoption of the well developed criminal law of the States and Territories is a preferable course to the creation of new Commonwealth law to deal with these very particular and, in the Australian context, hopefully rare circumstances. It should be noted, however, that the provisions of State and Territory legislation, and the relevant common law principles, will be applied as federal law.

Clauses 8, 9 and 10 of the Bill make necessary incidental provision for the handling of any prosecutions which, by virtue of section 68 of the Judiciary Act, will be heard in State courts. Clause 11 will preclude the raising of defences of exceptional circumstances or superior orders. Clause 13 recognises the obligation under article 6 of the Convention to allow an alleged offender who is not an Australian citizen access to his or her country's diplomatic or consular representatives. The remaining clauses ensure that State and Territory laws are not displaced, make appropriate provision for the Act's application and adopt the Convention's definition of torture.

It remains for me to explain why it was considered unnecessary to include certain other provisions which might appear to be called for by the Convention. The obligations under Article 5 to establish jurisdiction when offences are committed on an Australian ship or aircraft are already fulfilled by the Crimes at Sea 1979 and the Crimes (Aircraft) Act 1963. The other categories in that Article are, I believe, encompassed by the Bill or by existing State and Territory law. Obligations in relation to extradition are fulfilled by our extradition law, treaties and practice. Obligations under Article 16 in relation to cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment or punishment which do not amount to torture are, in the Government's view, fulfilled by State and Territory criminal law, and the obligation under Article 14 to provide for fair and adequate compensation for the victim of an act of torture is met by State criminal injuries compensation legislation and by common law rights in tort.

The passage of this Bill will be a significant step in the international effort to combat torture. Whether or not the occasion ever arises for the legislation to be invoked, its existence will be a clear indication to the international community that Australia will never become a safe haven for those who breach fundamental human rights. It will also provide a practical means of dealing with any situation where a person who is alleged to have committed acts of torture overseas is found within Australian territory.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill and I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: NATIONAL COMPANIES AND SECURITIES COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1988

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tate) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the National Companies and Securities Commission Amendment Bill 1988 is to amend section 21 of the National Companies and Securities Commission Act 1979 so as to clarify the power of the National Companies and Securities Commission (NCSC) to give a general direction to a Division established by the NCSC. In addition the Bill will retrospectively validate any past directions to a Division under section 21 of the NCSC Act. The Bill will not, however, necessarily operate retrospectively where a past direction under section 21 is the subject of Court proceedings that are in progress when the amendment commences operation.

Section 21 of the NCSC Act in its present form permits the NCSC, by resolution, to direct that its functions or powers in relation to `a matter' be performed or exercised by a Division of the NCSC. The purpose of section 21 is to enable the NCSC to make the most efficient use of the limited number of its members by delegating certain of its functions or powers to a smaller Division.

The present Bill is necessary to overcome the doubt now cast on the provision by comments made by some members of the Full Court of the Supreme Court of Victoria, in a recent as yet unreported case (NCSC v Sim, 23 February 1988) on the power of the NCSC to give a general direction to Divisions. In that case it was said by those members that the reference to `a matter' in section 21 of the Act appeared to contemplate specificity in the resolution, and would not enable a general bestowal by the NCSC of all its functions and powers upon a Division.

The section if construed in this way would mean that the NCSC's method of operating through Divisions would be fettered in that each individual matter would require a specific direction. It would not be possible for the NCSC to give a general direction to a Division that it exercise or perform the powers or functions of the NCSC.

It was not the intention that the ambit of section 21 be confined in this way. Indeed, since the formation of the NCSC in 1979 it has been accepted practice for its standing Divisions (which now comprise the Companies, Takeovers, Executive, Securities Industry and Futures Industry Divisions) to perform most of the NCSC's day-to-day decision-making functions. In addition the NCSC has given a general direction that all matters arising under the legislation for which it is responsible are able to be exercised by the relevant Division.

It is also desirable that the amendment preserve the validity of past actions by a Division of the NCSC to avoid possible administrative dislocation and public confusion which would result if previous decisions or acts were to be nullified. However, to protect the rights of those persons who may have already begun proceedings against the NCSC, the amendment will not apply in those cases to retrospectively validate the NCSC direction in question, except where the Court decides that it would be just and equitable for the direction to be treated as valid.

The Bill, therefore aims to redress any misconceptions about the intended operation of section 21 and endeavours to ensure that the NCSC can conduct its business through its Divisions by virtue of either general or specific grants of power. In accordance with the Commonwealth's obligations under the Formal Agreement establishing the Co-operative Companies and Securities Scheme, this Bill was approved by the Ministerial Council for Companies and Securities on 17 March 1988.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this Bill.

ANSWER.PARA: When interviewed by the Australian Federal Police (AFP) in December 1987, Dr Menon undertook to provide information to assist in establishing whether or not there was any substance to his allegations of fraud within the Health Insurance Commission. Despite discussion with the AFP on three separate occasions, I am advised that Dr Menon has provided the police with no material which would substantiate his allegations.

The honourable senator's suggestion that electronic funds transfer (EFT) is somehow involved in the alleged fraud, shows a total lack of knowledge and understanding of the Medicare computer system. EFT is not employed by the Commission in any of its claims payment transactions.

The Medicare computer was not programmed to cope with re-use of these numbers and, as a result, the claims payment system directed cheques to incorrect locations and providers.
Approximately 12 doctors were affected by this error in the period before it was rectified. One of these was Dr White.

As I mentioned earlier, the relevant cheques were stopped and replacement cheques have been reissued to the doctors to whom these benefit payments should have been made for the services listed. Therefore, the cheques held by Mr Menon and tabled by the honourable senator are merely worthless pieces of paper.
